The ship was on this run.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>At Panama canal, a\nBritish Tank Cleaning Suptd used to embark, to do the final cleaning and wall\nwash tests. This man was paid a fortune just to be on board for 3 days. He was\nsort of indispensable.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>The wall wash tests\nused to be done electronically by Mass spectrometer , instead of using lab\nreagents for HC,and Chlorides. The lore on the ship was , that things happen\nlike magic after this Limey comes from UK. Till then the tanks fail miserably\nin the wall wash. <o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>So after I&nbsp; took over command ,&nbsp; the Brit came on board. Our zinc tanks were\nclean already , and was good enough for Methanol but was failing on the\nspectrometer.&nbsp; Jose also has a similar\nspectrometer donated by the French Charterers.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>I gave instructions to\nthe Chief Officer.&nbsp; Once the Brit tank\ncleaning suptd comes on board, he must be watched every time he comes to the\nCCR near the spectrometer. If he fiddles around with it, I must be called down\nimmediately. <o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Sure enough Chief\nofficer calls me . : Sir, he is fiddling around with the machine right now, he\ndoes NOT know that we are watching him\u201d.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>I immediately came down\nand caught him in the act , literally with his pants down \u201c Why are you\nfiddling around with the span and sensitivity adjustments?&nbsp; I demand an explanation!.&nbsp; You have just altered the Quadratic equation\ncoding !. So this is how you make yourself indispensable \u2013by shining at the\nexpense of the poor ship staff \u201d.<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>His face and body\nlanguage explained it all. font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b>INDIAN SAGES WERE\nINVITED TO FOREIGN NATIONS TO TEACH THEM COMPOSTING&nbsp;&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></b></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><br /></b></span></div>\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\"><b><span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;\"></span>\n</b></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; color: red; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b>THE ANCIENT INDIAN\nSAGES WHO ENSURE THAT OUR TOP SOIL WAS HUMUS LADEN DID NOT NEED ANY MODERN CHOOTIYA INSTRUMENTS. &nbsp;&nbsp;</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; color: red; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; color: red; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b>WIKIPEDIA AND THEIR TWO INDIAN POODLES CAN FUCK THEMSELVES &nbsp;</b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; color: red; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; color: red; font-size: large;\"><b>THEY USED THEIR FIVE SENSES AND THEIR ABILITY TO SEE THE AURA OF\nHUMUS.</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the process of\ncomposting, microorganisms break down organic matter and produce carbon\ndioxide, water, heat, and <b style=\"background-color: white;\">HUMUS</b>, the relatively stable organic end product. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Under optimal\nconditions, composting proceeds through three phases: 1) the mesophilic, or\nmoderate-temperature phase, which lasts for a couple of days, 2) the\nthermophilic, or high-temperature phase, which can last from a few days to\nseveral months, and finally, 3) a several-month cooling and maturation phase.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bacteria in a compost\npit can be classified by their optimal growth temperature. The following are\nthe five classifications:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hyperthermophile (60\ndegrees C and upwards)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thermophile (optimal\ngrowth between 45 and 122 degrees)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mesophile (20 and 45\ndegrees C)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Psychrotrophs (will\nsurvive at 0 degrees C, but prefer mesophilic temperature<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Psychrophiles (-15 and\n10 degrees C or lower)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A C:N ratio ranging\nbetween 25:1 and 30:1 is the optimum combination for rapid decomposition. If\nratio is more than 30:1 carbon, heat production drops and decomposition slows..\nWhen there is too much nitrogen, your compost &nbsp;pile will likely release the excess as smelly\nammonia gas. Too much nitrogen can also cause a rise in the pH level which is\ntoxic to some microorganisms.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As the microorganisms\nwork to decompose the compost, they give off heat which in turn increases pile\ntemperatures. Temperatures between 32 deg C &nbsp;to 60 deg&nbsp;\nindicate rapid decomposition. Lower temperatures signal a slowing in the\ncomposting process. High temperatures greater than 60&nbsp; deg C reduce the activity of most organisms.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/M1kIpCBD3UI/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/M1kIpCBD3UI?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Composting organisms\nrequire four equally important ingredients to work effectively:--<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Carbon \u2014 for energy;\nthe microbial oxidation of carbon produces the heat, -- carbon materials tend\nto be brown and dry.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrogen \u2014 to grow and\nreproduce more organisms to oxidize the carbon.&nbsp;&nbsp; High nitrogen materials tend to be green (or\ncolorful, such as fruits and vegetables) and wet.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Oxygen \u2014 for oxidizing\nthe carbon, the decomposition process.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Water \u2014 in the right\namounts to maintain activity without causing anaerobic conditions.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Rapid composting is\nfavored by having a C/N ratio of&nbsp; 30 or\nless.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">All organic matter has\na ratio of Carbon to Nitrogen (C:N) in their tissues<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For microorganisms,\ncarbon is the basic building block of life and is a source of energy, but\nnitrogen is also necessary for such things as proteins, genetic material, and\ncell structure<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Decomposition of\norganic materials in your compost pile is greatly increased when you create the\nproper balance between the carbonaceous materials (called BROWN because they\nare dry) and the nitrogen-rich materials (called GREEN because they are more fresh\nand moist).<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/hOELM8V7p74/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/hOELM8V7p74?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For best performance,\nthe compost pile--- the composting microorganisms, require the correct\nproportion of Carbon for energy and Nitrogen for protein production.&nbsp;&nbsp; The fastest way to produce fertile,\nsweet-smelling compost is to maintain a C:N ratio somewhere around 25 to 30\nparts Carbon to 1 part Nitrogen, or 25-30:1.&nbsp;&nbsp;\n<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Again, if the C:N ratio\nis too high (excess Carbon), decomposition slows down.&nbsp;&nbsp; If the C:N ratio is too low (excess\nnitrogen) you will end up with a stinky pile.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/o0Hf_IcS_5U/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/o0Hf_IcS_5U?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Microorganisms that\ndigest compost need about 30 parts of carbon for every part of nitrogen they\nconsume. That's a balanced diet for them. If there's too much nitrogen, the\nmicroorganisms can't use it all and the excess is lost in the form of smelly\nammonia gas. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Why you don't want too much\nnitrogen (fresh manure, for example) in your compost: the nitrogen will be lost\nin the air in the form of ammonia gas, and nitrogen is too valuable for plants\nto allow it to escape into the atmosphere.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A maximum of 35% of the carbon in\nfresh organic material will be converted into soil humus IF there is sufficient\nnitrogen present.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The humus formed from\nthe decomposition of fresh organic material will contain approximately 50%\ncarbon and 5% nitrogen. In other words, the C:N ratio of the humus is 10:1.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/-RAu0rrZlWU/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/-RAu0rrZlWU?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Most fresh plant\nmaterial contains 40% carbon. The C:N ratio varies because of differences in\nnitrogen content, NOT carbon content. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Again-<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Any organic matter that\nhas a C:N ratio generally smaller than 30:1 is considered a GREEN.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Any organic matter that\nhas a C:N ratio generally larger than 30:1 is considered a BROWN.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">All organic matter is\nmade up of substantial amounts of carbon (C) combined with lesser amounts of\nnitrogen (N).&nbsp;&nbsp; The balance of these two\nelements in an organism is called the carbon-to-nitrogen ratio (C:N ratio).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A carbon-to-nitrogen\nratio (C/N ratio or C:N ratio) is a ratio of the mass of carbon to the MASS of\nnitrogen in a substance. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Example of devices that\ncan be used to measure this ratio are the CHN analyzer and the continuous-flow\nisotope ratio mass spectrometer (CF-IRMS)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As the name implies, a\nCHN Analyzer is a scientific instrument which can determine the elemental\nconcentrations in a given sample. It is used to measure Carbon (C), Hydrogen\n(H) and Nitrogen (N). Sample sizes may differ depending on system, but most\noften in around a few mg..&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This instrument uses combustion to oxidize the\nsample into simple compounds which are then detected with thermal conductivity\ndetection or infrared spectroscopy. Separation of interference is done by\nchemical reagents\u2026<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mass spectrometry (MS)\nis an analytical technique that ionizes chemical species and sorts the ions\nbased on their mass-to-charge ratio. In simpler terms, a mass spectrum measures\nthe masses within a sample.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Microorganisms such as\nbacteria, fungi, and actinomycetes are considered chemical decomposers, because\nthey change the chemistry of organic wastes.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The larger decomposers, or macroorganisms, in a compost pile include\nmites, centipedes, sow bugs, snails, millipedes, springtails, spiders, slugs,\nbeetles, ants, flies, nematodes, flatworms, rotifers, and earthworms.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">They are\nconsidered to be physical decomposers because they grind, bite, suck, tear, and\nchew materials into smaller pieces.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/iAiRNq8JXw8/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/iAiRNq8JXw8?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Of all these organisms,\naerobic bacteria are the most important decomposers. They are very abundant;\nthere may be millions in a gram of soil or decaying organic matter.&nbsp; You would need 26,000 of them laid end to end\non a ruler to make an inch.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">They are the most\nnutritionally diverse of all organisms and can eat nearly anything&nbsp; . Bacteria utilize carbon as a source of\nenergy (to keep on eating) and nitrogen to build protein in their bodies (so\nthey can grow and reproduce). They obtain energy by oxidizing organic material,\nespecially the carbon fraction.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This oxidation process\nheats up the compost pile from ambient air temperature. If proper conditions\nare present, the pile will heat up fairly rapidly (within days) due to bacteria\nconsuming readily decomposable materials.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">While bacteria can eat\na wide variety of organic compounds, they have difficulty escaping unfavorable\nenvironments due to their size and lack of complexity. Changes in oxygen,\nmoisture, temperature, and acidity can make bacteria die or become inactive. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Aerobic bacteria need\noxygen levels greater than five percent. They are the preferred organisms,\nbecause they provide the most rapid and effective composting. They also excrete\nplant nutrients such as nitrogen, phosphorus, and magnesium. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When oxygen levels fall\nbelow five percent, the aerobes die and decomposition slows by as much as 90\npercent <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">BUT THEN ANAEROBIC\nBACTERIA SEAMLESSLY TAKES OVER, THEY NEED METHANE FOR SRIVINAL, NOT OXYGEN<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is the TRINITY of\nBrahma / Vishnu and Shiva working on a micro scale \u2013the basis of DVAITA Vedanta</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Anaerobic\nmicroorganisms take over and, in the process, produce a lot of useless organic\nacids and amines (ammonia-like substances) which are smelly, contain\nunavailable nitrogen and, in some cases, are toxic to plants.&nbsp;&nbsp; In addition, anaerobes produce hydrogen\nsulfide (aroma-like rotten eggs), cadaverine, and putrescine (other sources of\noffensive odors).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are different\ntypes of aerobic bacteria that work in composting piles. Their populations will\nvary according to the pile temperature. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Psychrophilic bacteria\nwork in the lowest temperature range. They are most active at 13 deg C and will\nwork in the pile if the initial pile temperature is less than 21\u00ba deg C. They\ngive off a small amount of heat in comparison to other types of bacteria. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The heat they produce\nis enough however, to help build the pile temperature to the point where\nanother set of bacteria, mesophilic bacteria, start to take over.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mesophilic bacteria\nrapidly decompose organic matter, producing acids, carbon dioxide and heat.\nTheir working temperature range is generally between 21 deg C to 38 deg CF.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the pile temperature rises above&nbsp; 38\ndeg C , the mesophilic bacteria begin to die off or move to the outer part of\nthe heap.&nbsp;&nbsp; They are replaced by\nheat-loving thermophilic bacteria.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thermophilic bacteria\nthrive at temperatures ranging from&nbsp; 45\ndeg C to 71 deg CF. Thermophilic bacteria continue the decomposition process,\nraising the pile temperature 55 deg C to 71 deg C, where it usually stabilizes.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Unless a pile is constantly fed new\nmaterials and turned at strategic times, the high range temperatures typically\nlast no more than three to five days&nbsp; .\nThermophilic bacteria use up too much of the degradable materials to sustain\ntheir population for any length of time.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As the thermophilic bacteria decline\nand the temperature of the pile gradually cools off, the mesophilic bacteria\nagain become dominant. The mesophilic bacteria consume remaining organic\nmaterial with the help of other organisms.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Different communities\nof microorganisms predominate during the various composting phases. Initial\ndecomposition is carried out by mesophilic microorganisms, which rapidly break\ndown the soluble, readily degradable compounds. The heat they produce causes\nthe compost temperature to rapidly rise.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As the temperature\nrises above about 40\u00b0C, the mesophilic microorganisms become less competitive\nand are replaced by others that are thermophilic, or heat-loving. At\ntemperatures of 55\u00b0C and above, many microorganisms that are human or plant\npathogens are destroyed.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Because temperatures over about 65\u00b0C kill many forms\nof microbes and limit the rate of decomposition, compost managers use aeration\nand mixing to keep the temperature below this point.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">During the thermophilic\nphase, high temperatures accelerate the breakdown of proteins, fats, and\ncomplex carboydrates like cellulose and hemicellulose, the major structural\nmolecules in plants. As the supply of these high-energy compounds becomes\nexhausted, the compost temperature gradually decreases and mesophilic microorganisms\nonce again take over for the final phase of \"curing\" or maturation of\nthe remaining organic matter.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bacteria are the\nsmallest living organisms and the most numerous in compost; they make up 85% of\nthe billions of microorganisms typically found in a gram of compost.&nbsp; Bacteria are responsible for most of the\ndecomposition and heat generation in compost.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">They are the most nutritionally\ndiverse group of compost organisms, using a broad range of enzymes to\nchemically break down a variety of organic materials.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When conditions become\nunfavorable, bacilli survive by forming endospores, thick-walled spores that\nare highly resistant to heat, cold, dryness, or lack of food. <o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/Nw0MXW9mwak/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/Nw0MXW9mwak?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The characteristic\nearthy smell of soil is caused by actinomycetes, organisms that resemble fungi\nbut actually are filamentous bacteria. Like other bacteria, they lack nuclei,\nbut they grow multicellular filaments like fungi.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In composting they play an\nimportant role in degrading complex organics such as cellulose, lignin, chitin,\nand proteins. Their enzymes enable them to chemically break down tough debris\nsuch as woody stems, bark, or newspaper.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Some species appear during the\nthermophilic phase, and others become important during the cooler curing phase,\nwhen only the most resistant compounds remain in the last stages of the\nformation of humus.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fungi include molds and\nyeasts, and collectively they are responsible for the decomposition of many\ncomplex plant polymers in soil and compost. In compost, fungi are important\nbecause they break down tough debris, enabling bacteria to continue the\ndecomposition process once most of the cellulose has been exhausted.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;They\nspread and grow vigorously by producing many cells and filaments, and they can\nattack organic residues that are too dry, acidic, or low in nitrogen for\nbacterial decomposition.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Most fungi are classified as saprophytes\nbecause they live on dead or dying material and obtain energy by breaking down\norganic matter in dead plants and animals. Fungal species are numerous during\nboth mesophilic and thermophilic phases of composting.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Most fungi live in the\nouter layer of compost when temperatures are high. Compost molds are strict\naerobes that grow both as unseen filaments and as gray or white fuzzy colonies\non the compost surface.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Protozoa are one-celled\nmicroscopic animals. They are found in water droplets in compost but play a\nrelatively minor role in decomposition. Protozoa obtain their food from organic\nmatter in the same way as bacteria do but also act as secondary consumers ingesting\nbacteria and fungi.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Rotifers are\nmicroscopic multicellular organisms also found in films of water in the\ncompost. They feed on organic matter and also ingest bacteria and fungi.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The drop in compost\npile temperature is not a sign that composting is complete, but rather an\nindication that the compost pile is entering another phase of the composting\nprocess.&nbsp; If the pile temperature exceeds\n71 deg C, you may want to take action and cool the pile by turning it&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil amended with compost can help fight\nfungal infestations.&nbsp;&nbsp; If the compost\npile temperature goes above&nbsp; 71 deg C,\nthe composting material may become sterile and lose its disease fighting\nproperties.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/n9Mnf9ysNSs/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/n9Mnf9ysNSs?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Actinomycetes, a higher-form bacteria similar\nto fungi and molds, are responsible for the pleasant earthy smell of compost.\nGrayish in appearance, actinomycetes work in the moderate heat zones of a\ncompost pile. They decompose some of the more resistant materials in the pile\nsuch as lignin, cellulose, starches, and proteins. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As they reduce materials,\nthey liberate carbon, nitrogen, and ammonia, making nutrients available for\nhigher plants. Actinomycetes occur in large clusters and become most evident\nduring the later stages of decomposition.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Like bacteria and\nactinomycetes, fungi are also responsible for organic matter decay in a compost\npile. Fungi are primitive plants that can be either single celled or many\ncelled and filamentous. They lack a photosynthetic pigment. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Their main contribution\nto a compost pile is to break down cellulose and lignin, after faster acting\nbacteria make inroads on them. They prefer cooler temperatures 23 deg C and\neasily digested food sources. As a result, they also tend to take over during\nthe final stage of composting.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Larger organisms are\ninvolved in physically transforming organic material into compost. They are\nactive during the later stages of composting \u2013 digging, chewing, sucking,\ndigesting and mixing compostable materials.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In addition to mixing materials, they\nbreak it into smaller pieces, and transform it into more digestible forms for\nmicroorganisms. Their excrement is also digested by bacteria, causing more\nnutrients to be released.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Micro- and\nmacroorganisms are part of a complex food chain. This food chain consists of\norganisms classified as either first-, second-, or third-level consumers. The\ncategories are based on what they eat and who eats them. First level consumers\nbecome the food for second level consumers, which in turn, are eaten by third\nlevel consumers. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mites and springtails\neat fungi. Tiny feather-winged beetles feed on fungal spores. Nematodes ingest\nbacteria. Protozoa and rotifers present in water films feed on bacteria and\nplant particles. Predaceous mites and pseudoscorpions prey upon nematodes, fly\nlarvae, other mites and collembolans.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Free-living flatworms\ningest gastropods, earthworms, nematodes and rotifers. Third-level consumers\nsuch as centipedes, rove beetles, ground beetles, and ants prey on second-level\nconsumers.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Earthworms are the most\nimportant of the large physical decomposers in a compost pile. <o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\">Artificial fertilisers\nof the GREEN REVOLUTION killed all micro and macro organisms in the top soil.</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\">But hey, our PM Modi loves GM foods, GM chemical fertilisers and toxic\npersticides.&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: large;\">After desh drohi Verghese Kurian\u2014 ask the people of Gujarat, who is\nNo 2 traitor in decimating our priceless Vedic humped cows.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: large;\">Ask Gujaratis \u2014not the rest of India</span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<a href=\"http://www.indiatvnews.com/news/india/modi-had-a-public-spat-8-years-ago-with-v-kurien-17648.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://www.indiatvnews.com/news/india/modi-had-a-public-spat-8-years-ago-with-v-kurien-17648.html</a><o:p></o:p></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-ac1MrpU6oi8/WR2GQw-QwNI/AAAAAAABTbI/rjVFOUm_sQQU5dVA7yR7dGUFwTuT3RydQCLcB/s1600/Verghese_Kudrien_with_Prince_Charles.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"400\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-ac1MrpU6oi8/WR2GQw-QwNI/AAAAAAABTbI/rjVFOUm_sQQU5dVA7yR7dGUFwTuT3RydQCLcB/s400/Verghese_Kudrien_with_Prince_Charles.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"line-height: 200%;\"><b style=\"background-color: white;\"><span style=\"color: purple; font-size: large;\">Desh Drohi Verghese Kurian ( this crypto Jew\nis from Calicut ) switched our priceless HUMPED Vedic cows with useless , </span><span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\">worse\nthan pigs </span><span style=\"color: purple; font-size: large;\">HUMPLESS western Jersey cows.&nbsp;</span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"line-height: 200%;\"><b style=\"background-color: white;\"><span style=\"color: purple; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"line-height: 200%;\"><b style=\"background-color: white;\"><span style=\"color: purple; font-size: large;\">Bharatmata will stop bleeding only if we decimate 100% --all HUMPLESS\ncows and bulls.</span></b><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-tAIQp1OSD1o/WR2GupR8EFI/AAAAAAABTbM/etObD985hbMKDYfh0doDitRgOTvmDoR7wCLcB/s1600/vwwerghese-kurien.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"640\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-tAIQp1OSD1o/WR2GupR8EFI/AAAAAAABTbM/etObD985hbMKDYfh0doDitRgOTvmDoR7wCLcB/s640/vwwerghese-kurien.jpg\" width=\"500\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Earthworms ingest\norganic matter and digest it with the help of tiny stones in their gizzards.\nTheir intestinal juices are rich in hormones, enzymes, and other fermenting\nsubstances that continue the breakdown process.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The worms leave dark, fertile\ncastings behind. A worm can produce its weight in castings each day. These\ncastings are rich in plant nutrients such as nitrogen, calcium, magnesium, and\nphosphorus that might otherwise be unavailable to plants.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Earthworms thrive on\ncompost and contribute greatly to its quality. The presence of earthworms in\neither compost or soil is evidence of good microbial activity.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Organic material\nprovides food for organisms in the form of carbon and nitrogen. As described\nearlier, bacteria use carbon for energy and protein to grow and reproduce.\nCarbon and nitrogen levels vary with each organic material.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Carbon-rich\nmaterials tend to be dry and brown such as leaves, straw, and wood chips.\nNitrogen materials tend to be wet and green such as fresh grass clippings and\nfood waste.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A tip for estimating an organic material\u2019s carbon/nitrogen content\nis to remember that fresh, juicy materials are usually higher in nitrogen and\nwill decompose more quickly than older, drier, and woodier tissues that are\nhigh in carbon.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Proper aeration is a\nkey environmental factor. Many microorganisms, including aerobic bacteria, need\noxygen. They need oxygen to produce energy, grow quickly, and consume more\nmaterials. Aeration involves the replacement of oxygen deficient air in a\ncompost pile with fresh air containing oxygen.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Natural aeration occurs when air\nwarmed by the composting process rises through the pile, bringing in fresh air\nfrom the surroundings. Aeration can also be affected by wind, moisture content,\nand porosity (spaces between particles in the compost pile). Composting reduces\nthe pile\u2019s porosity and decreases air circulation.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Porosity can be negatively\naffected if large quantities of finely sized materials such as pine needles,\ngrass clippings, or sawdust are used. In addition, air circulation can be\nimpeded if materials become water saturated.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Air movement in the\npile can be improved with a few simple techniques. The easiest way to aerate a\npile is to regularly turn it with a pitchfork or shovel. Turning will fluff up\nthe pile and increase its porosity. Another option is to add coarse materials\nsuch as leaves, straw, or corn stalks. Other options include using a compost\naeration tool (available from garden supply companies) <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Decomposer organisms\nneed water to live. Microbial activity occurs most rapidly in thin water films\non the surface of organic materials. Microorganisms can only utilize organic\nmolecules that are dissolved in water. The optimum moisture content for a\ncompost pile should range from 40 to 60 percent.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;If there is less than 40\npercent moisture, bacteria slow down and may become dormant. If there is more\nthan 60 percent, water will force air out of pile pore spaces, suffocating the\naerobic bacteria. Anaerobic bacteria will take over, resulting in unpleasant\nodors.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The ideal percentage of\nmoisture will depend on the organic material\u2019s structure. Straw and corn stalks\nwill need more moisture than leaves, while food waste or grass clippings are\nnot likely to need additional moisture.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Since it is difficult to measure\nmoisture, a general rule of thumb is to wet and mix materials so they are about\nas moist as a wrung-out sponge. Material should feel damp to the touch, with\njust a drop or two of liquid expelled when squeezed in your hand.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If a compost pile is\ntoo dry, it should be watered as the pile is being turned or with a trickling\nhose. Certain materials such as dead leaves, hay, straw, and sawdust should be\ngradually moistened until they glisten.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;These types of materials have a\ntendency to shed water or adsorb it only on the surface. If a pile is saturated\nwith water, turn it so that materials are restacked. It may also help to add dry,\ncarbon rich material.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Stimulate bacteria and\nspeed up decomposition. Low winter temperatures will slow or temporarily stop\nthe composting process. As air temperatures warm up in the spring, microbial\nactivity will resume. During winter months, compost piles can be covered with a\ntarp to help retain heat longer, but it is not necessary.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;The most accurate readings will come from a\ncompost thermometer or temperature probe. Compost thermometers are available\nfrom many garden supply companies.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">You can also place a\nmetal pipe or iron bar in the middle of the pile, periodically pulling it out\nand feeling it.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: large;\"><b>Wikipedia and their two\nIndian poodle can stick in the balls or twats \u2013as the case may be.</b></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: large;\"><b>&nbsp;Remember to shove some Panchgavya up your technical assholes first</b></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">If the bar or the\ninterior of the pile feels uncomfortably warm or hot during the first few weeks\nof composting, you\u2019ll know everything is fine. If the temperature inside the\npile is the same as the outside, that is an indication that the composting\nprocess is slow. You can increase activity by adding nitrogen rich material and\nturning the pile.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Particle size affects\nthe rate of organic matter breakdown. The more \u201csurface area\u201d available, the\neasier it is for microorganisms to work, because activity occurs at the\ninterface of particle surfaces and air.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Microorganisms are able to digest more,\ngenerate more heat, and multiply faster with smaller pieces of material.\nAlthough it is not required, reducing materials into smaller pieces will\ndefinitely speed decomposition.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Organic materials can be chopped, shredded,\nsplit, bruised, or punctured to increase their surface area. Don\u2019t \u201cpowder\u201d\nmaterials, because they will compact and impede air movement in the pile.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Kitchen scraps can be\nchopped up with a knife. Some ambitious people use meat grinders and blenders\nto make \u201cgarbage soup\u201d from their food scraps and water. They pour the mixture\ninto their heaps.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The process involves\ndecomposition of organic waste into humus known as compost which is a good\nfertilizer for plants.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">High C:N ratios may be\nlowered by adding grass clippings or manures. Low C:N ratios may be raised by\nadding paper, dry leaves or wood chips.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is better to put up\nwith a slight odor and keep some excess nitrogen in the pile, just to make sure\nthere is always enough around to keep the pile \u201ccooking\u201d</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><span style=\"color: red;\">MATERIAL&nbsp;&nbsp; C:N RATIO</span></b><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ashes, wood&nbsp;&nbsp; 25:1 ( <span style=\"background-color: white;\"><b>VILLAGE WOMEN MUST COOK WITH WOOD \u2013NOT\nLPG-- FUCK AL GORE&nbsp;</b></span> )<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fruit waste&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 35:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hay, green&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 25:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Leaves, other&nbsp;&nbsp; 60:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Manure and cow&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 20-25:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Paper&nbsp;&nbsp; 180:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Weeds &nbsp; &nbsp; 25:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Wood chips&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 500-700:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cardboard, shredded&nbsp; &nbsp;350:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Corn stalks&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 75:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Newspaper, shredded 175:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sawdust&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 325:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Straw&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;75:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Wood chips&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 400:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Food waste&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 20:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Grass clippings&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 20:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Manures&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp; 15:1</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vegetable scraps&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 25:1</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If your compost mix is\ntoo low in nitrogen, it will not heat up.&nbsp;\nIf the nitrogen proportion is too high, the compost may become too hot,\nkilling the compost microorganisms, or it may go anaerobic, resulting in a\nfoul-smelling mess. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The usual recommended\nrange for C/N ratios at the start of the composting process is about 30/1, but\nthis ideal may vary depending on the bioavailability of the carbon and\nnitrogen.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;As carbon gets converted to CO2 (and assuming minimal nitrogen\nlosses) the C/N ratio decreases during the composting process, with the ratio\nof finished compost typically close to 10/1.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Browns are any plant\nmaterial that is brown, and includes fall leaves, dried grass, wood products,\npaper and straw. Greens are&nbsp; fresh grass\nclippings, freshly picked weeds, plant clippings and most kitchen scraps.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Calling composting\ningredients brown or green is useful because it is simple for people to understand.\nHowever the terms are not always correct. It would be better to use the terms\nhigh nitrogen ingredient, and low nitrogen ingredient. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The greens contain\nhigher levels of nitrogen. For example, fresh green plant material contains\nhigh levels of nitrogen.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As the greens age they\nlose nitrogen and turn brown at the same time. Green leaves have high levels of\nnitrogen, but as they go brown in fall, the nitrogen levels drop. Wood products\nand straw have low levels of nitrogen.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">So is manure a brown or\na green? Based on color it is a brown, but based on nitrogen levels it is a\ngreen. As far as composting goes, it\u2019s a green.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow;
