font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\">The ideal C:N ratio is\n\u201c 30 parts brown to 1 part green\u201d, is just wrong- if you have the brains to\nunderstand the term C:N ratio.&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\">It is not\na ratio of browns to greens.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\">It is a\nratio of carbon to nitrogen.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The carbon\nto nitrogen ratio in the compost pile should be 30:1, not the ratio of browns\nto greens.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Composting is a process\nwhereby microbes degrade the organic matter added to the compost pile. These\nmicrobes have basic requirements for food, just like you and me. It turns out\nthey grow best when there is a ratio of carbon to nitrogen of about 30:1.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The right amount of\ncarbon and nitrogen makes the microbes happy, and they grow fast. Fast growing\nmicrobes means that the composting process happens quickly and the pile heats\nup to desirable temperatures. So for fast compost it is important to feed the\nmicrobes the right ratio of carbon:nitrogen.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Organisms get rid of\nexcess N as ammonia.&nbsp; Humped cow urine is\ngood source of nitrogen besides it contains sulphur.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Humpless cow urine and dung is NOT good for\nsoil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vedic humped cow urine\ncontains phosphate, potassium, sodium, manganese, carbolic acid, iron, silicon,\nchlorine, salt, enzyme and hormones. It strengthens the fact that cow\u2019s urine\nis not a toxic effluent as&nbsp; 95% of its\ncontent being water, 2.5% urea and the remaining 2.5% a mixture of minerals,\nsalts, hormones and enzymes.&nbsp;&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is also considered\nas a natural disinfectant and pest repellent and forms the main component of\nPanchagavya, an organic crop booster prepared and sprayed by Indian farmers. As\nproducts of ecological sanitation, urine is eminently suitable for use as\nfertilizer as they contain essential nutrients needed for plant growth. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Panchagavya consists of\nnine products viz. cow dung, cow urine, milk, curd, jaggery, ghee, banana,\ntender coconut, and water. The cow dung and ghee are thoroughly mixed in the\nmorning and evening, and kept for 3 days. After setting, it is mixed regularly\nfor another 15 days, and then added to the other ingredients, and left to sit\nfor another 30 days. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Panchagavya is stored\nin a wide-mouthed earthen pot or concrete tank in open. Sufficient shade is\nusually provided. It is diluted before use.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The term \u2018\u2018composting\u2019\u2019\nis used to de\ufb01ne the process of controlled bio-logical maturity under aerobic\nconditions, where organic matter of animal or vegetal origin is decomposed to\nmaterials with shorter molecular chains, more stable,hygienic, humus rich, and\n\ufb01nally bene\ufb01cial for the agricultural crops and for recyclingof soil organic\nmatter. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The process is mediated\nby different micro-organisms actuating in aerobic environment: bacteria, fungi,\nactinomycetes, algae,and protozoa, which participate naturally in the organic\nbiomass or are added artificially <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrogen is necessary\nfor the growth of organisms and consequently to maximize the generation of heat.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Limitations of Hot\nComposting:--<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The two inevitable\nlosses are nitrogen and humus (through the loss of carbon). Nitrogen is lost\nby--<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">--leaching of nitrates<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">--loss of ammonia which\nis generated too rapidly for incorporation into biomass<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">--denitrification.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Humus is lost by-<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">--oxidation of carbon<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">--lack of nitrogen for\ntissue generation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">An obvious alternative\nto hot composting is cold composting - gather materials into a pile without\nregard to the C/N ratio, adding to it as materials accumulate, and let it\nsit.&nbsp; In time, anywhere from a few weeks\nto a few months&nbsp; it takes on the\nappearance of soil and can be spread. Better yet is to add soil in order to\nabsorb excess moisture and improve aeration by reducing compaction.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrogen losses will\nalso occur in cold compost.&nbsp; Leaching of\nnitrates is probably more extensive than in hot compost because the pile is\nexposed longer to the environment.&nbsp; Owing\nto the slow rate of decomposition, however, ammonia loss should be minimal,\nunless animal manure is a major component. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Although the demand for\noxygen is much less than it is in hot compost, denitrification is still likely\nbut to a lesser extent. Denitrification can, however be further reduced by\nadding soil to increase aeration.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Even though cold\ncomposting does not destroy disease organisms directly, its results probably\nhelp to control them, owing to the ecological balance resulting from the\nincreased diversity of organisms.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A final note\nillustrates the difference between the two processes.&nbsp; &nbsp;Liming\na cold compost pile to a pH near 7 is advisable because it will encourage the\ndevelopment of a greater variety of micro-organisms. Fungi will proliferate at\nalmost any pH, but bacteria tend to prefer a neutral environment.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Never, however, lime a\nhot compost pile and probably not any pile containing a substantial amount of\nfresh animal manure: doing so will accelerate the escape of ammonia and\nsubsequent loss of nitrogen.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Compost concentrates\nnutrients because of the loss of bulk. This loss depends upon the initial C/N\nratio of the residues; the higher the ratio, the greater the loss of bulk and\nthe greater the concentration of nutrients. On the other hand, the loss of bulk\nmeans less humus.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\">WE ASK THE GOVT TO\nGLEAN THIS BLOGPOST AND MAKE \u201cKRISHI DARSHAN \u201c MOVIES FOR VILLAGERS.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 200%;\"><b style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">HAVE\nA MOBILE CELL IN EVERY VILLAGE TO HELP FARMERS IN UNDERSTANDING CARBON:\nNITROGEN RATIO TO CREATE HUMUS LADEN COMPOST&nbsp;</span></b><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 200%;\"><b style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></b></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 200%;\"><b style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\">HAVE GOVT OUTLETS IN EVERY VILLAGE SELLING ORGANIC HUMUS MANURE INSTEAD OF CHEMICAL FERTILISERS AND PESTICIDES</span></b></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 250%;\"><b style=\"background-color: white;\">WE ASK PM MODI TO INCLUDE GROUND WATER CONSERVATION\n&nbsp;AND COMPOSTING &nbsp;( ORGANIC HUMUS LADEN MANURE ) IN HIS MANN KI\nBAATH .&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<b style=\"background-color: white;\"><br /></b></div>\n<b style=\"background-color: white;\"><br /></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 250%;\"><b style=\"background-color: white;\">PM MODI-- &nbsp; &nbsp;FOR A CHANGE DO SOMETHING FOR THE\nWATAN RATHER THAN FOR JEW ROTHSHILD\u2014 &nbsp; PRAISING ALL HIS FAKE CREATIONS AND AGENTS TO\nTHE SKIES IN A FAALTHU MANNER&nbsp;</b><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><b><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></b></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 250%;\"><b><span style=\"color: purple;\">AND HULLO VANDANA SHIVA<o:p></o:p></span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 250%;\"><b><span style=\"color: purple;\">STOP SEEKING THE LIMELIGHT FOR FAALTHU PERSONAL\nGAIN<o:p></o:p></span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 250%;\"><b><span style=\"color: purple;\">DO DOMETHING CONSTRUCTIVE FOR THE WATAN.<o:p></o:p></span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 250%;\"><b><span style=\"color: purple;\">AND HULLLO----&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 250%;\"><b><span style=\"color: purple;\">MAKE THAT BINDI ON YOUR FOREHEAD SMALLER \u2013&nbsp;&nbsp; AS A SIGN THAT YOU ARE NOW IN THE PURSUIT OF\nGREATER GOALS<o:p></o:p></span></b></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 250%;\"><b><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></b></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-4yes0xtGivQ/WR2pyCn2YLI/AAAAAAABTbg/QvLtFSsZyxw-PRBMfOGM_9lwZb0h6b5OgCLcB/s1600/Dr%252BVandWWWana%252BShiva%252BAttends%252BPeace%252BFestival%252BSydney%252B46IsNRCrwHVm.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"426\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-4yes0xtGivQ/WR2pyCn2YLI/AAAAAAABTbg/QvLtFSsZyxw-PRBMfOGM_9lwZb0h6b5OgCLcB/s640/Dr%252BVandWWWana%252BShiva%252BAttends%252BPeace%252BFestival%252BSydney%252B46IsNRCrwHVm.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 250%;\"><b><span style=\"color: purple;\">VANDANA BABY,&nbsp; &nbsp;IF I WERE TO HOLD AN OBJECTIVE EXAM FOR YOU, &nbsp;&nbsp;YOU WILL SCORE ZERO RIGHT NOW.<o:p></o:p></span></b></span></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><b><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></b></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Approximately half of\nthe compost breaks down in the soil during the first year after application,\nand so about half of the nitrogen and sulfur should become available the first\nseason.&nbsp;&nbsp; Much of the phosphorus in\ncompost is in inorganic form; although a significant amount should be readily\navailable&nbsp;&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Most of the calcium,\nand magnesium in the original residues is no longer in organic form and will\nbecome available immediately. Most of the potassium is never in organic form\nand is always available; indeed leaching losses can be significant.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The quickest way to\nproduce rich garden humus is to create a hot, or active, compost pile.&nbsp;&nbsp; It is called \u201chot\u201d because it can reach an\ninternal temperature of 65 deg C and \u201cactive\u201d because it destroys, essentially\nby cooking, weed seeds and disease-causing organisms.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A hot compost pile\nshould be 4 -foot cube is preferred. The pile will shrink as the ingredients\ndecompose.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Check the temperature\nof the pile with a compost thermometer or an old kitchen thermometer. A\ntemperature of 57 deg C is desirable. If you have no heat or insufficient heat,\nadd nitrogen in the form of soft green ingredients or organic fertilizer.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If a foul odor emanates\nfrom the pile, flip the compost to introduce more air. And consider: Did you\nadd meat or dairy products?&nbsp; Remove and\ndiscard them, if possible.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">To cold compost, pile\norganic materials (leaves, grass clippings, soil, cow dung etc\u2014but avoid dog,\ncat, and human shit) as you find or accumulate them.&nbsp;&nbsp; Bury kitchen scraps in the center of the\npile to deter insects and animals.&nbsp;&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Avoid adding meat,\ndairy, and fat. Also avoid weeds; cold compost piles do not reach high\ntemperatures and do not kill weed seeds. (In fact, weeds may germinate in a\ncold pile.)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A hot pile requires\nenough high-nitrogen materials to get the pile to heat up.. To aid in\ndecomposition, keep the mixture as damp as a wrung-out sponge but not sopping\nwet.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A variety of different-size mate rials (like twigs, stalks, straw, or hay)\ncreates air pockets. You also increase the air/oxygen exchange every time you\nturn the pile.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If the pile is built\ncorrectly, it will heat up within 24 to 36 hours to the ideal temperature of 65\ndeg C (weed seeds and disease pathogens die at these temperatures) and will\nmaintain its temperature for several days to a week or longer. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: large;\">Use a compost\nthermometer to monitor the temperature. &nbsp; &nbsp;Wikipedia and their two Indian poodles\ncan use their balls or twats as applicable-- with some <span style=\"color: red;\">Panchagavya up their technical assholes&nbsp;</span>for good measure .</span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;If the temperature starts to drop or if it\ngets hotter than 71 deg C&nbsp; turn the pile\nagain and add water. This should be done several times. A hot pile takes more\neffort but will produce compost more quickly\u2014in several weeks to several\nmonths.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cold composting\nrequires minimal effort but may 9 months before it produces compost you can use\n. In hot tropical India it happens fast<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The time needed to have\nfinished compost is hard to estimate because it depends on the materials in\nyour pile and the size of the particles. The smaller the particles, the faster\nthey will break down. Do not put in weeds that have gone to seed or diseased\nplants. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Without high\ntemperatures to kill off weed seeds or disease pathogens, you will be spreading\nthese bad guys around your landscape.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hot composting kills\nweed seeds faster. The higher the temperature the more seeds are destroyed.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Remember, weed seeds\nwill survive in 'cold' composting heaps.&nbsp;\nThis will screw up all your hard work.&nbsp; &nbsp; The problem is made worse as the seeds are planted in nature's best\ngrowing medium - humus/compost.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\">Below: In case you add weeds to </span><span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\">cold compost</span><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: large; line-height: 150%;\">-- make sure you first kill the weed and its seeds by high temperatures. &nbsp; 93 deg C for 20 minutes will kill the weed and its seeds&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/tqLf8MvHsiY/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/tqLf8MvHsiY?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hot composting kills\npathogens and unwelcome bacteria. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">You need to leave cold\ncompost a long time (9- 12 months) to achieve the same level of sanitisation\nand bacteria to die off.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Always wear gloves and wash hands.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Herbicides and\npesticides are broken down in composting. They are broken down 32 times faster\nat 60\u00b0c than at 10\u00b0c.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">At 10\u00b0c the heap it is\n32 times slower than at 60\u00b0C. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">All composting produces\nother odours - known as volatile organic chemicals. These often have an odour.\nThis is more noticeable in hot composting as they are made faster and the heat\nvaporises them. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In a cold heap, water\nis not evaporated; it has to drain to the ground. This happens slowly and\npoorly in compost, so it gets water logged and turns anaerobic and putrid. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The main solution is\nnot to add 'wet' food waste to cold heaps - most of our diet is foods with 80%\nwater. Cold composting releases VOC more slowly and they do not vaporise as\nmuch.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A hot bin will kill fly\neggs and larvae - so no swarms of flies or maggots in a hot compost bin. It's\ntoo hot at the top for ants, rats, and most things you don\u2019t like to see in a\nheap.&nbsp; Flies will lay eggs and\nlarvae (e.g. maggots) will be present in a cold heap, and often swarms of flies\ncan come out when lid open.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Heat loss is the reason\nwhy a compost pile takes so long to decompose. Observers have noted that the\ntime taken to create compost can be dramatically reduced by retaining the heat\nin a suitably insulated container.. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Compost becomes\nanaerobic due to the absence of air, and this can result in it becoming smelly.\nBy adding large, medium and fine items to the top of the container, space is\nprovided in between the items for the air to flow from bottom to top. This\ncreates a trickle ventilation. Compost made with this method is called aerobic\ncomposting (no smell).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Important:--Temperatures\nhigher than 72 degrees causes the important hyperthermic bacteria to die off\nand defeats the plan.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hot container\ncomposters aim for a temperature range of between 35 degrees C and 65 degrees C\nto aid optimal bacterial decomposition. A suitable thermometer, analogue or\ndigital, is needed for monitoring this.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is due to the most\nof the decomposition work taking place on the top of the pile&nbsp; (where the heat is concerntrated) <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cold compost pile:--&nbsp; Attracts vermin e.g. mice and rats due to\nodour of decomposing materials and some warmth it can offer. Read this line\ntwice<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: cyan;\">Compost is a soil amendment, not a\nfertilizer, because it does so much more than just provide nutrients such as\nnitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium (N-P-K).</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both;
