font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">INSTEAD OF\nCRYING HOARSE ABOUT INDIAN MEN NEEDING TO RAPE LESS WOMEN , AND INDIAN MEN NEEDING TO CHANGE\nMINDSETS\u2014 <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background: aqua; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">THODA KAAM KA\nBAATH KARO !<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"background: aqua; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-OyrdM_9LmVg/WR28qcp8AQI/AAAAAAABTcI/69PPkird1EsTR03tsWtjS7qFk_wHIbokwCLcB/s1600/imDDDages.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"210\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-OyrdM_9LmVg/WR28qcp8AQI/AAAAAAABTcI/69PPkird1EsTR03tsWtjS7qFk_wHIbokwCLcB/s400/imDDDages.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background: aqua; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">WHEN I\nWANT TO LAUGH MY GUTS OUT, &nbsp;I WATCH THIS PEA\nBRAINED TV ANCHOR FAYE DSOUZA --</span><br />\n<span style=\"background: aqua; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background: aqua; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">IF SHE WAS CAPTAIN OF A SHIP--- &nbsp; IN ONE MINUTE THE CREW WILL THROW HER OVERBOARD&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/JFGQR5ERaPQ/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/JFGQR5ERaPQ?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vermicompost is the\nproduct of the composting process using various species of worms, usually red\nwigglers, white worms, and other earthworms, to create a heterogeneous mixture\nof decomposing vegetable or food waste, bedding materials, and vermicast. This\nprocess of producing vermicompost is called vermicomposting.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vermicast (also called\nworm humus ) is the end-product of the breakdown of organic matter by an\nearthworm.] These castings have been shown to contain reduced levels of\ncontaminants and a higher saturation of nutrients than do organic materials\nbefore vermicomposting.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vermicompost contains\nwater-soluble nutrients and is an excellent, nutrient-rich organic fertilizer\nand soil conditioner. It is used in organic farming.<span style=\"background: aqua; mso-highlight: aqua;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/nccbpQ1l9ME/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/nccbpQ1l9ME?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 250%;\"><b style=\"background-color: white;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">THE GREEN REVOLUTION FATHER \u2013&nbsp; REALLY MISTER SUPER CUT - &nbsp;&nbsp;HAD NO IDEA WHAT EARTHWORMS DO- &nbsp; &nbsp;BECAUSE CHEMICAL FERTILIZERS DECIMATED THE EARTHWORMS</span></b><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Earth worms are found\nin organic-rich soils and live in rotting vegetation, compost, and manure\npiles.&nbsp;&nbsp; As they are shallow-dwelling and\nfeed on decomposing plant matter in the soil, they adapt easily to living on\nfood or plant waste in the confines of a worm bin.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In vermicomposting, the\nearthworms take over both the roles of turning and maintaining the material in\nan aerobic condition, thereby reducing the need for mechanical operations. In\naddition, the product (vermicompost) is homogenous.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\"><b>Indians were the first\non the planet to do Vermicomposting</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Earthworms have been on\nthe Earth for over 20 million years. In this time they have faithfully done\ntheir part to keep the cycle of life continuously moving. Their purpose is\nsimple but very important.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">They are nature\u2019s way of recycling organic nutrients\nfrom dead tissues back to living organisms. The earthworm is a natural resource\nof fertility and life. Earthworms are commonly found living in soil, feeding on\nlive and dead organic matter.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">An earthworm's digestive system runs through the\nlength of its body. It conducts respiration through its skin.. Earthworms are\nhermaphrodites\u2013each individual carries both male and female sex organs.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Earthworms are typically active only if water is present. Earthworms travel\nunderground by the means of waves of muscular contractions which alternately\nshorten and lengthen the body.. Earthworms work as biological\n\"pistons\" forcing air through the tunnels as they move.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thus\nearthworm activity aerates and mixes the soil, and is conducive to\nmineralization of nutrients and their uptake by vegetation. Certain species of\nearthworm come to the surface and graze on the higher concentrations of organic\nmatter present there, mixing it with the mineral soil.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Because a high level of\norganic matter mixing is associated with soil fertility, an abundance of\nearthworms is generally considered beneficial by the organic gardener.. The\nmajor benefits of earthworm activities to soil fertility can be summarized as:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Biological: In many\nsoils, earthworms play a major role in the conversion of large pieces of\norganic matter into rich humus, thus improving soil fertility. This is achieved\nby the worm's actions of pulling below the surface deposited organic matter\nsuch as leaf fall or manure, either for food or to plug its burrow.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Once in the\nburrow, the worm will shred the leaf and partially digest it and mingle it with\nthe earth. Worm casts (see bottom right) can contain 40 percent more humus than\nthe top 9\" (23 cm) of soil in which the worm is living.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Faeces are in form of casts.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Chemical: In addition\nto dead organic matter, the earthworm also ingests any other soil particles\nthat are small enough\u2014including sand grains up to 1.25\nmm\u2014into its gizzard, wherein those minute fragments of grit grind everything\ninto a fine paste which is then digested in the intestine.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the worm\nexcretes this in the form of casts, deposited on the surface or deeper in the soil,\nminerals and plant nutrients are changed to an accessible form for plants to\nuse fresh earthworm casts are five times richer in available nitrogen, seven\ntimes richer in available phosphates, and 11 times richer in available\npotassium than the surrounding upper 6 inches (150 mm) of soil.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In conditions\nwhere humus is plentiful, the weight of casts produced may be greater than 4.5\nkg per worm per year.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The earthworm's burrowing creates a multitude of\nchannels through the soil and is of great value in maintaining the soil\nstructure, enabling processes of aeration and drainage.. by sliding in their\ntunnels, earthworms \"act as an innumerable army of pistons pumping air in\nand out of the soils on a 24-hour cycle (more rapidly at night)\"</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thus, the earthworm not only creates passages for air and water to traverse the\nsoil, but also modifies the vital organic component that makes a soil healthy\n(see Bioturbation). Earthworms promote the formation of nutrient-rich casts\n(globules of soil, stable in soil [mucus]) that have high soil aggregation and\nsoil fertility and quality.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The ability to break down organic materials and\nexcrete concentrated nutrients makes the earthworm a functional contributor in\nrestoration projects. In response to ecosystem disturbances,..&nbsp; Earthworms positively influence the rate of\nmacroaggregate formation, an important feature for soil structure.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;The\nstability of aggregates in response to water was found to be improved when\nconstructed by earthworms.While, as the name earthworm suggests, the main\nhabitat of earthworms is in soil, the situation is more complicated than that.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The brandling worm Eisenia fetida lives in decaying plant matter and manure.\nEarthworm populations depend on both physical and chemical properties of the\nsoil, such as temperature, moisture, pH, salts, aeration, and texture, as well\nas available food, and the ability of the species to reproduce and disperse.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrogenous fertilizers tend to create acidic conditions, which are fatal to\nthe worms, and dead specimens are often found on the surface following the\napplication.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The addition of organic matter, preferably as a surface mulch, on\na regular basis will provide earthworms with their food and nutrient\nrequirements, and will create the optimum conditions of temperature and\nmoisture that will stimulate their activity.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Earthworms are vital to soil\nhealth and to plants growing in it because they transport nutrients and\nminerals from below to the surface via their waste. An earthworm can eat up to\na third of its body weight in a day.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Earthworms come in a seemly infinite\nvariety\u2014around 6,000 species worldwide. The earthworm\u2019s digestive system is a\ntube running straight from the mouth, located at the tip of the front end of\nthe body, to the rear of the body, where digested material is passed to the\noutside.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Species vary in what they eat, but by and large their devouring of\nfallen leaves and/or soil allows the worms to move nutrients such as potassium\nand nitrogen into the soil. They are the main contributors to enriching and\nimproving soil for plants, animals and even humans.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Earthworms create tunnels\nin the soil by burrowing, which aerates the soil to allow air, water and\nnutrients to reach deep within the soil. Earthworms eat the soil which has\norganic matter such as decaying vegetation or leaves.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Plants cannot use this\norganic matter directly.&nbsp; After organic\nmatter is digested, the earthworm releases waste from their bodies called\ncastings. Castings contain many nutrients that the plant can use. Some people\neven use earthworm castings as garden fertilizer. Worm castings are the richest\nnatural fertilizer known to humans.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Worm castings stimulate plant growth more\nthan any other natural product on the market. Unlike animal manure and\nartificial fertilizers it is absorbed easily and immediately by plants.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/9wyFwpy8WUE/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/9wyFwpy8WUE?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">But\nWorm Castings don't only stimulate plant growth: they also enhance the ability\nof your soil to retain water (because of its texture), and it even inhibits\nroot diseases such as root rot.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Worm Castings contain a highly active\nbiological mixture of bacteria, enzymes, remnants of plant matter and animal\nmanure, as well as earthworm cocoons (while damp). The castings are rich in\nwater-soluble plant nutrients, and contain more than 50% more humus than what\nis normally found in topsoil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/jJ3QIZMta98/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/jJ3QIZMta98?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Worm Castings are\npacked with minerals that are essential for plant growth, such as concentrated\nnitrates, phosphorus, magnesium, potassium and calcium. It also contains\nmanganese, copper, zinc, cobalt, borax, iron, carbon and nitrogen.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">However, the\nbest of all is that these minerals are immediately available to the plant,\nwithout the risk of ever burning the plant. Remember that animal manure and\nchemical fertilizers have to be broken down in the soil before the plant can\nabsorb them.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As the organic matter\nmoves through the alimentary canal of the earthworm, a thin layer of oil is\ndeposited on the castings. This layer erodes over a period of 2 months. So\nalthough the plant nutrients are immediately available, they are slowly\nreleased to last longer.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div style=\"text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/ORu_mdB7cng/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/ORu_mdB7cng?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;The cocoons in Worm Castings each contain between 2\nand 10 eggs that hatch within 2 weeks. This means that the process of\ndecomposition are continued by the young earthworms in the soil, provided that\nthe soil is loose, damp and rich enough in organic matter for the worms to stay\nalive.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The bacteria in the\nalimentary canal of the earthworm transforms organic waste to natural\nfertilizer. The chemical changes that the organic wastes undergo include\ndeodorizing and neutralizing. This means that the pH of the castings is 7\n(neutral) and the castings are odorless (they smell like a forest after rain).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The worm castings also contain the bacteria, so the process is continued in the\nsoil, and microbiological activity is promoted.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Worm Castings will ensure that\nthe minerals are absorbed directly into the soil when it is watered. Because\nWorm Castings will never burn plants, you can use as much of it as you like.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Benefits of Worm\nCastings:--<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The humus in the worm\ncastings extracts toxins and harmful fungi and bacteria from the soil. Worm\nCastings therefore have the ability to fight off plant diseases.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The worm castings have\nthe ability to fix heavy metals in organic waste. This prevents plants from\nabsorbing more of these chemical compounds than they need. These compounds can\nthen be released later when the plants need them.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Worm Castings act as a\nbarrier to help plants grow in soil where the pH levels are too high or too\nlow. They prevent extreme pH levels from making it impossible for plants to\nabsorb nutrients from the soil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/bugUPPKXFDw/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/bugUPPKXFDw?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The humic acid in Worm\nCastings stimulate plant growth, even in very low concentrations. The humic\nacid is in an ionically distributed state in which it can easily be absorbed by\nthe plant, over and above any normal mineral nutrients. Humic acid also\nstimulates the development of micro flora populations in the soil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Worm Castings increase\nthe ability of soil to retain water. The worm castings form aggregates, which\nare mineral clusters that combine in such a way that they can withstand water\nerosion and compaction, and also increase water retention.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/TP-Lc4mmgYo/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/TP-Lc4mmgYo?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Worm Castings reduce\nthe acid-forming carbon in the soil, and increase the nitrogen levels in a\nstate that the plant can easily use. Organic plant wastes usually have a\ncarbon-nitrogen ratio of more than 20 to 1.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Because of this ratio, the nitrogen\nis unavailable to plants, and the soil around the organic waste becomes acidic.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Worm humus is the\nend-product of the breakdown of organic matter by species of earthworm.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Containing\nwater-soluble nutrients, vermicompost is a nutrient-rich organic fertilizer and\nsoil conditioner in a form that is relatively easy for plants to absorb.&nbsp; Worm castings are&nbsp; organic fertilizer.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Because the earthworms\ngrind and uniformly mix minerals in simple forms, plants need only minimal\neffort to obtain them. The worms' digestive systems create environments that\nallow certain species of microbes to thrive to help create a \"living\"\nsoil environment for plants.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The fraction of soil which has gone through the\ndigestive tract of earthworms is called the Drilosphere.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Worm composts can also\nbe used to clean up heavy metals. The researchers found substantial reductions\nin heavy metals when the worms were released into the garbage and they are\neffective at removing lead, zinc, cadmium, copper and manganese.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Compost teas are defined\nas water extracts brewed from composted materials and can be derived from\naerobic or anaerobic processes.&nbsp; Compost\nteas are generally produced from adding one volume of compost to 4-10 volumes\nof water &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Field studies have shown the benefits of adding compost teas to crops\ndue to the adding of organic matter, increased nutrient availability and\nincreased microbial activity.&nbsp; They have\nalso been shown to have an effect on plant pathogens.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Pet wastes from cats,\ndogs, meat-eating animals and birds will contain disease organisms<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These organisms are\ndestroyed by high heat, but home composting typically doesn\u2019t reach the\nnecessary temperatures. Manure from plant-eating animals can be composted\nsafely but should be done only in a hot pile.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Synthetic fertilizers\ndestroy natural nitrogen found in the soil. Which means farmers must use\nincreasing amounts of the fertilizers each year just to sustain their\nyields.&nbsp; Nitrogen application severely\npollutes water supplies.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Farmers apply nitrogen\nfertilizer to crops to help them grow, but only about half of that nitrogen is\ntaken up by plants.&nbsp; The rest leak out\ninto the environment.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">And because cows, pigs and poultry gobble up heaps of\ncorn and soy feed, more nitrogen fertilizer is applied \u2014 and emitted \u2014 in the\nprocess of producing meat than other foods.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Raising beef produces\nalmost 20 times as much nitrogen pollution as growing the same amount of bean\nprotein, <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrogen fixation,\nwhich is required for the growth of higher plants, is hindered by pesticides in\nsoil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">With the proper mixture\nof water, oxygen, carbon, and nitrogen, micro-organisms are able to break down\norganic matter to produce compost. The composting process is dependent on\nmicro-organisms to break down organic matter into compost.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Composting can destroy\npathogens or unwanted seeds. Unwanted living plants (or weeds) can be\ndiscouraged by covering with mulch/compost</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Containing\nwater-soluble nutrients, vermicompost is a nutrient-rich organic fertilizer and\nsoil conditioner in a form that is relatively easy for plants to absorb.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Compost is rich in\nnutrients. The compost itself is beneficial for the land in many ways,\nincluding as a soil conditioner, a fertilizer, addition of vital humus or humic\nacids, and as a natural pesticide for soil. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Composting of waste is\nan aerobic (in the presence of air) method of decomposing solid wastes. Again,\nthe process involves decomposition of organic waste into humus known as compost\nwhich is a good fertilizer for plants. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">With the proper mixture\nof water, oxygen, carbon, and nitrogen, micro-organisms are able to break down\norganic matter to produce compost. The composting process is dependent on\nmicro-organisms to break down organic matter into compost. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are many types of\nmicroorganisms found in active compost of which the most common are:---<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bacteria- The most\nnumerous of all the microorganisms found in compost. Depending on the phase of\ncomposting, mesophilic or thermophilic bacteria may predominate.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Actinobacteria-\nNecessary for breaking down paper products such as newspaper, bark, etc.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fungi- molds and yeast\nhelp break down materials that bacteria cannot, especially lignin in woody\nmaterial.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Protozoa- Help consume\nbacteria, fungi and micro organic particulates.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Rotifers- Rotifers help\ncontrol populations of bacteria and small protozoans.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Compost is rich in\nnutrients. The compost itself is beneficial for the land in many ways,\nincluding as a soil conditioner, a fertilizer, addition of vital humus or humic\nacids, and as a natural pesticide for soil. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Composting of waste is\nan aerobic (in the presence of air) method of decomposing solid wastes. Again,\nthe process involves decomposition of organic waste into humus known as compost\nwhich is a good fertilizer for plants. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">With the proper mixture\nof water, oxygen, carbon, and nitrogen, micro-organisms are able to break down\norganic matter to produce compost. The composting process is dependent on\nmicro-organisms to break down organic matter into compost. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Earthworms not only\ningest partly composted material, but also continually re-create aeration and\ndrainage tunnels as they move through the compost. Earthworms are sensitive to\nchanges in climate. Extreme temperatures and direct sunlight are not healthy\nfor the worms.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">The best temperatures\nfor vermicomposting range from</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">14 deg C\nto 27 deg C.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As a soil amendment,\ncompost will improve soil structure and tilth.&nbsp;&nbsp;\nCompost will also help soil hold more moisture and allows plant roots to\npenetrate more easily.&nbsp; Adding compost to\nyour soil will increase the number and type of microbes in the soil, helping\nplants obtain nutrients and keeping a balance among microbes to help limit the\nnumber of disease causing organisms.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The overall benefit of\nusing compost as a soil amendment is that it improves soil health, which in\nturn can lead to healthier plants. Compost is THE key ingredient in organic\nfarming. Finished compost has an earthy, greenhouse smell.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Microorganisms living\nin a compost pile need enough moisture to survive. Water is the key element\nthat helps transports substances within the compost pile and makes the\nnutrients in organic material accessible to the microbes. Organic material\ncontains some moisture in varying amounts, but moisture also might come in the\nform of rainfall or intentional watering.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Again,in cold composts\ndo not add diseased plants or any portion of invasive weed plants or their\nseeds, as your compost might not reach high enough temperatures to destroy the\ndisease or viable parts of plants and their seeds. &nbsp;Grazing humped cow are an important part of\nregenerative agriculture\u2014as their urine and dung is priceless.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c5696002339303227942\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_116M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/02322936501999137085\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Sudesh Soogrim</a></cite><span class=\"icon user\" style=\"font-weight: bold;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2017/05/groundwater-resources-of-india-part-6.html?showComment=1495160332950#c5696002339303227942\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">May 19, 2017 at 7:48 AM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_116MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nKalki Avatar has been kicked in? What is making Europe so warm ?<br />\n<br />\nNitrous oxide, a highly potent greenhouse gas is now being released from a warming Arctic<br />\n<br />\nNitrous oxide emissions have increased from Arctic peatlands following permafrost thaw- caused by Methane release.<br />\n<br />\nIf the GLOBAL WARMING POTENTIAL ( GWP ) is 1 for Carbon Dioxide, it is 302 for Nitrous oxide and 104 for Methane over a 20 year period.<br />\n<br />\nPARIS COP21 KICKED METHANE AND NITROUS OXIDE UNDER THE KOSHER CARPET SO THAT THE JEWS CAN BLAME CO2 AS THE VILLAIN AND MAKE MONEY OUT OF THIN AIR ( CARBON CREDIT- OFFSET ).<br />\n<br />\nAT THE G20 SUMMIT IN HAMBURG 2017- ALL WORLD LEADERS ( INCLUDING MODI ) WERE IN JEW ROTHSCHILDs POCKET EXCEPT DONALD TRUMP.<br />\n<br />\nhttp://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/04/most-potent-greenhouse-gases-nitrous.html<br />\n<br />\nWE ASK PM MODI\u2014WHAT IS THE USE OF HAVING AN ICE STATION HEMADRI AT ARCTIC? HAVE THE SCIENTISTS GONE THERE TO HAVE BOOZE AND ENJOY ?<br />\n<br />\nMore than 70 billion tons of nitrogen stocks are stored in the upper 3.5 metres of permafrost soil, a vast sum accumulated over thousands of years through the nitrogen cycle<br />\n<br />\nThe permafrost stocks are more than 600 times larger than the annual nitrogen load added as GM fertiliser to soils globally<br />\n<br />\nSome of that nitrogen already exists in the form of \u201cold\u201d nitrous oxide, built up during the permafrost formation, while other mineralized nitrogen interacts with microbes to produce \u201cnew\u201d nitrous oxide.<br />\n<br />\nNitrous oxide that is released into the atmosphere remains in the troposphere for more than a century and then it migrates to the stratosphere, where it depletes the ozone layer. The ozone layer serves as a protective barrier absorbing solar radiation; without it the sun\u2019s ultraviolet rays would severely damage biological organisms, including humans.<br />\n<br />\nAlthough the Montreal Protocol, an international treaty signed in 1987 to protect the ozone layer, Nitrous oxide was ignored. The Zionist Jews concentrated on WEE ozone depleting items ( like refrigerants ) where they can make money out of thin air.<br />\n<br />\nLoss of nitrogen to the atmosphere may also reduce plant biomass, further contributing to climate change.<br />\n<br />\nIf nitrogen is lost to the atmosphere, plant growth won't be able to compensate for carbon being lost from permafrost soils<br />\n<br />\nThe most alarming phenomenon in the Arctic is the loss of the highly reflective snow and ice cover, known as the albedo..<br />\n<br />\nHigh nitrous oxide saturations were recently observed in productive shallow Arctic shelf waters following significant reduction in sea ice cover..<br />\n<br />\nNitrous oxide is produced in the ocean water column and sediments by two pathways. The first is in oxygen-rich conditions in which ammonium is converted to nitrate, creating nitrous oxide as a byproduct. The second occurs in deoxygenated sediments where nitrous oxide is produced in an intermediate stage between the conversion of nitrate to nitrogen gas.<br />\n<br />\nThe loss of sea ice cover in Arctic shelf waters has resulted in increased sunlight absorption, fueling phytoplankton growth. Following phytoplankton death, organic material is remineralized to ammonium, which can be converted to nitrate and ultimately produce nitrous oxide.<br />\n<br />\nWhat happens in the Arctic doesn\u2019t stay in the Arctic ( unlike the Cricket team dressing room politics )<br />\n<br />\nIndians were the first to use BIOCHAR for agriculture . It converts agricultural waste into a soil enhancer that can hold carbon, boost food security, and increase soil biodiversity, and discourage deforestation. The process creates a fine-grained, highly porous charcoal that helps soils retain nutrients and water.<br />\n<br />\nIndia was blessed with HUMUS laden topsoil with healthy microbes and earthworms for millions of years. Just 55 years of desh drohi GREEN REVOLUTION has decimated our holy topsoil.<br />\n<br />\n90% of our lakes have disappeared.<br />\n<br />\n<br />\nCONTINUED TO 2--</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" id=\"bc_0_140BR\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; text-decoration-line: none;\">August 6, 2017 at 9:34 AM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_138MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nCONTINUED FROM 1--<br />\n<br />\nOur hospitals are full die to the effects of NITROSAMINES and EVIL PHARMA is laughing all the way to the bank with \u201cAlice in Wonderland \u201c PM Modi clapping from the sidelines<br />\n<br />\nhttp://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2017/05/nitrate-water-pollution-chemical.html<br />\n<br />\nRead all 6 pats of the post below--<br />\nhttp://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2017/05/ground-water-resources-of-india-capt.html<br />\n<br />\nWE WANT OUR NCERT TEXT BOOKS TO EXPOUND THE IMPORTANCE OF HAVING HUMUS LADEN TOP SOIL AND BASICS ABOUT GRAOUND WATER .<br />\n<br />\nOrganic soil forms can be further divided into \"recalcitrant carbon\" or resistant to decay, like humus, and \"labile carbon,\" where the carbon is both bioavailable (in the form of easily degraded compounds such as oils, sugars and alcohols) and physically accessible to microbes (not bound up with minerals).<br />\n<br />\nThe organic carbon pool includes both the living bodies and the dead, decomposing bodies of bacteria, fungi, insects and worms, along with plant debris and manure<br />\n<br />\nIndian topsoil was 6 feet deep\u2014unlike other nations of this planet having a few inches deep top soil.<br />\n<br />\nModern, chemically-based GM agriculture depletes soil carbon..<br />\n<br />\nWHAT IS GOOD FOR ISRAEL IS NOT GOOD FOR INDIA\u2014 JEW DARLING PM MODI PLEASE NOTE. WE WONT ALLOW YOUR MANN KE TAMANNA \u201cKOSHER COMPUTER COW\u201d IN INDIA..<br />\n<br />\nSoil building is the product of a self-reinforcing, positive feedback loop. But soil decline is also a self-reinforcing loop that can result in catastrophic soil loss.<br />\n<br />\nNitrogen fertilizers combined with tillage accelerate microbial respiration, burning up soil carbon faster than it is replaced. Due to the loss of organic carbon reservoirs, many soils have become nearly lifeless substrates that must be continually fed with irrigation water, mineral nutrients and pesticides to produce a crop. Although productive in the short term, this practice is not sustainable<br />\n<br />\nThe desh drohi GREEN REVOLUTION has caused our holy topsoil to lose 80% of their original soil organic carbon (SOC) pool.<br />\n<br />\nWE DON\u2019T WANT COMMIES AND WHITE JEWS TO DRIVE OUR EDUCATION<br />\n<br />\nBiochar serves as an electron buffer for redox reactions and helps bacteria swap electrons among themselves, improving their metabolic efficiency as a microbial community.. With its pores and its electrical charges, biochar is capable of both aBsorption and aDsorption.. The surfaces of biochar, both internal and external, aDsorb materials by electro-chemical bonds, working like an electric sponge.<br />\n<br />\nBiochar surfaces adsorb carbon and retain it in compounds with minerals, supporting at the same time a large microbial community that potentially makes more efficient use of organic debris containing carbon and other nutrients.<br />\nbalanced compost, with the optimum C:N ratio, will contain lots of humus. However, if there is not enough stable carbon (from wood, straw or other lignin sources), then the easily degradable sugars, fats and proteins will be completely consumed by microbes leaving very little substrate behind<br />\n<br />\nBoth biochar and compost increases cation exchange capacity (CEC - the ability to hold onto and transfer nutrient cations: ammonium, calcium, magnesium, and potassium)\u2026<br />\n<br />\nThey supports soil microbial life and biodiversity and helps plants resist diseases and pathogens. They add humus carbon to the soil carbon pool, reducing the atmospheric carbon pool\u2014and increases soil water holding capacity. In coastal areas they help plants grow better in high salt situations.<br />\n<br />\nUnlike biochar, compost is quickly broken down by microbial action in soil over months to at most, decades, depending primarily on climate. Biochar lasts at least ten times longer in most soils.. Biochar is effective at retaining nitrogen in soils and there is NO need for CHEMICAL UREA.<br />\n<br />\nTHIS IS THE ONLY INTELLIGENT WAY TO PREVENT FARMER SUICIDES.<br />\n<br />\n<br />\nCONTINUED TO 3--</div>\n<span class=\"comment-actions secondary-text\" id=\"bc_0_138MN\" kind=\"m\"><span class=\"item-control blog-admin pid-1783552029\" style=\"display: inline;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" id=\"bc_0_138BR\" style=\"margin-left: 36px; margin-top: 1em;\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-replybox-single\" id=\"bc_0_138B_box\" style=\"margin-left: 48px; margin-top: 5px;\">\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class=\"comment\" id=\"bc_0_139B\" kind=\"b\" style=\"border-bottom: 0px; margin: 0px 0px 16px; padding: 0.25em 0px 0px;\"><div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"float: left; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n<img src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-57G2xiZ-5tM/WJwrrVpmOmI/AAAAAAABQqo/-9wsspdm4RAiWSVRYXpBpkgoVBQdEyLRQCK4B/s35/*\" style=\"border: 1px solid rgb(238, 238, 238); max-width: 36px;\" /></div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c8131227607787448028\" style=\"margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_139M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2017/08/the-thin-red-line-movie-review.html?showComment=1501992304276#c8131227607787448028\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">August 6, 2017 at 9:35 AM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_139MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nCONTINUED FROM 2--<br />\n<br />\nAdding biochar to compost reduced the amount of dissolved organic carbon (labile carbon) in mature compost while increasing the fraction of stable humic materials (stable carbon).<br />\n<br />\nThe desh drohi GREEN REVOLUTION has left us with a rapidly deteriorating climate, and soils that are dying and eroding. Biochar, as a form of recalcitrant carbon, is the medicine that DELIBERETELY degraded and unproductive Indian top soils need.<br />\n<br />\nRECENTLY OUR LOSER LAWYER TURNED COLLEGIUM JUDGES ( BOTTOM DREGS OF THE SCHOOL CEREBRAL BARRE ) BANNED BURNING OF CROP STUBBLE ( WHICH PRODUCES BIOCHAR ) BECAUSE OF DELHI SMOG.<br />\n<br />\nIF THIS IS THE CASE SHIFT THE CAPITAL OF INDIA TO A PLACE WHERE THERE IS NO TEMPERATURE INVERSION..<br />\n<br />\nTall grasses burn quick and hot, however, close to the ground where the roots start, air is excluded so the base of the grasses will pyrolyze and not burn. This kind of natural charcoal is present in the most valuable agricultural soils in the world<br />\n<br />\nhttp://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/12/arctic-ice-melt-and-methane-time-bomb.html<br />\n<br />\nhttp://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/06/methane-time-bomb-arctic-ice-meltdown.html<br />\n<br />\nWHITE REVOLUTION and GREEN REVOLUTION has bled Bharatmata with a million cuts\u2014 the deep wound are pus filled sores today .<br />\n<br />\nhttp://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2013/07/nutritious-a1-milk-of-vedic-cows-with.html<br />\n<br />\nTHERE WAS A REASON WHY AGNIHOTRA WAS DONE IN ANCIENT TIMES IN INDIA.<br />\n<br />\nhttp://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2012/08/agnihotra-ghee-cow-dung-fuel-capt-ajit.html<br />\n<br />\nPUT THIS COMMENT IN THE WEBSITES OF PMO, PMMODI, EDUCATION MIISTER, HOME MIMISTER, FOOD MINISTER, HEALTH MINISTER, COAL MINISTER, FINANCE MINISTER, ENVIRONMENT MINISTER, LAW MINISTER CHIEF JUSTICE OF INDIA, AND WEBSITES OF DESH BHAKTS<br />\n<br />\nI ASK MY READERS \u2013 SPREAD THIS ON SOCIAL MEDIA.
