WHAT IS THIS VAIN WOMANs AGENDA?... WILL CITIES OF WESTERN\nNATIONS ALLOW DOGS TO RUN AROUND LIKE IN INDIA?... THEN WHY ARE THESE WHITE\nSKINNED BAST#RDS SUPPORTING MANEKA GANDHI AND HER DOG THINGY ?... WHO THE H#LL\nIS MANEKA GANDHI ?... IF SHE OVERDOES THIS-- I ASK MODI TO SACK HER .. DIES\nTHIS PEA BRAINED WOMAN KNOW THIS--\u2026 Dog po0p is NOT good fertilizer\u2026\u2026..\nEnvironmental Protection Agency (EPA) classified dog sh1t as a dangerous\npollutant in the same category as toxic chemicals \u2026\u2026. Dog sh1t in potable water\naffects the brain\u2026.. Dog sh1t spreads parasites including hookworms, ringworms,\ntapeworms and Salmonella\u2026. When infected dog sh1t comes into contact with your\nlawn, the sh1t will eventually \"disappear\", but the parasite eggs can\nlinger for years!... When a human or animal comes into contact with that soil\nthrough everyday activities like walking barefoot, gardening or playing, they\nrisk infection from those eggs ... even years after the p0op is gone. And a lot\nof Indians have split heels\u2026. Dog sh1it teams with E. Coli and other harmful\nbacteria including fecal coliform bacteria, which causes serious kidney\ndisorders, intestinal illness, cramps and diarrhea in humans. (There are 23.5\nmillion fecal coliform bacteria in a single gram of dog sh1t!) .. Dog sh1t\ncontains roundworm larvae, which cause blindness. If a human ingests a\nroundworm larva, it can migrate through the body causing disease to the brain,\nlungs, kidneys, liver, heart or eyes. So when people (especially children)\ntouch soil, or anything that has been in contact with dog sh1 then touch their\nmouths, they can become infected. .. Women who are pregnant are at risk of\nseveral zoonotic diseases from dog sh1t\u2026. WE ASK THE MODI GOVT , NOT TO ALLOW\nTHIS VAIN WOMAN TO SPREAD DISEASES IN INDIA\u2026. THERE ARE LOT OF STILL BORNS\nBECAUSE PREGNANT WOMEN INGESTED CONTAMINATED WATER . IN KERALA THE GROUND WATER\nLEVEL IS HIGH . .. THIS PROBLEM IS SO HUGE AND DANGEROUS THAT 3 YEARS AGO, I\nDUG UP THE EXTERIOR OF MY WELL TO EIGHT FEET ( TRENCH ) AND PUT IN WATER\nREPELLENT SAND COMPOUND ) SO THAT DOG SH1T DOES NOT SEEP IN\u2026\u2026 IN KERALA RATS\nLIKE TO EAT DOG SH1T ( PROTEIN ) AND THEN SNAKES COME IN TO EAT THOSE RATS\u2026.\nWHAT DOES THIS STUPID AND VAIN WOMAN MANEKA GANDHI KNOW ?.. SHE WAS CONVERTED\nINTO AN INTELLECTUAL BY PEA BRAINED SARDARJEE KHUSHWANT SINGH VIA HER TERRIBLE\nSURYA MAGAZINE IN 1975\u2026 capt ajit vadakayil ..<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Carbon to Nitrogen\nratio or C:N ratio is the mass of carbon to the mass of nitrogen in a\nparticular substance. For example, if we have a C:N ratio of 24:1, this means\nwe have 24 units of carbon to 1 unit of nitrogen. The C:N ratio is important\nbecause due to the fact that it has a direct impact on residue decomposition\nand also nitrogen cycling in our soils.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Our optimum C:N ratio\nis 24:1 for desired decomposition of our crop residue. The ratio 24:1 is the\nproper carbon and nitrogen that a microorganism must have in order sustain its\nhealth.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A microorganism living in the soil has a C:N ratio of about 8:1; this\nis what they must maintain in their bodies. For optimum health the microbe\nrequires approximately 16 parts of carbon for energy and then 8 parts for maintenance.\nThis is where the ratio of 24:1 comes from.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As a rule of thumb, the\nhigher the ratio, the longer it takes for the material to decompose. Likewise,\nthe smaller the ratio is, the more rapidly the plant material will decompose.\nThis also has a direct relationship with the amount of nitrogen that is tied up\nin the soil that will be available to the next growing plant.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The reason it takes\nlonger for the higher C:N ratio residue to decompose is due to the fact that\nthe further away form 24:1 we get, the more nitrogen the microbe must find from\nother sources in the soil. The microbes will pull all available nitrogen from\nthe soil that is necessary to reach its optimum ratio of 24:1.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This will lead\nto the excess nitrogen in the soil to be tied up (immobilization) and may lead\nto a deficit until some microbes die and release the nitrogen (immobilization)\nor other sources of nitrogen are provided. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As farm managers we can\nadjust our C:N ratios by blending certain types of crops with others. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Keep in mind the ratios\nchange as the plant grows, so the C:N ratio in a young plant will be much less\nas that compared to the plant as it fully matures. Also as we increase our soil\nhealth and have in place an established system or cycle, our microbial activity\nwill increase. Meaning that even our higher C:N ratio plants will begin to\nbreak down quicker. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A carbon-to-nitrogen\nratio (C/N ratio or C:N ratio) is a ratio of the mass of carbon to the mass of\nnitrogen in a substance. It can, amongst other things, be used in analysing\nsediments and compost. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">C/N ratios in the range\n8:1 are usually from marine sources, whereas higher ratios are likely to come\nfrom a terrestrial source. Vascular plants from terrestrial sources tend to\nhave C/N ratios greater than 20.&nbsp; The lack\nof cellulose, which has a chemical formula of (C6H10O5)n, and greater amount of\nproteins in algae versus vascular plants causes this significant difference in\nthe C/N ratio. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When composting,\nmicrobial activity utilizes a C/N ratio of 34:1 and a higher ratio will result\nin slower composting rates&nbsp; For practical\nagricultural purposes, a compost should have an initial C/N ratio of 25:1.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Example of devices that\ncan be used to measure this ratio are the CHN analyzer and the continuous-flow\nisotope ratio mass spectrometer (CF-IRMS).&nbsp;\nHowever, for more practical applications, desired C/N ratios can be\nachieved by blending common used substrates of known C/N content, which are\nreadily available and easy to use.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/ZgWLAkBvOG8/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/ZgWLAkBvOG8?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: left;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: left;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-size: large;\">Below: In India for several milliniums women cooked food on wood fires and then used the residue ashes as organic fertiliser. &nbsp; The Modi govt wants village women to pay money and buy LPG gas and cook. &nbsp; The invisible exhaust of such fires contain nano carbon which invade the blood brain barrier and cause myelin sheath damage</span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: left;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/745dJM5DvwY/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/745dJM5DvwY?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil carbon includes\nboth inorganic carbon as carbonate minerals, and as soil organic matter. Soil\ncarbon plays a key role in the carbon cycle<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil carbon is present\nin two forms: inorganic and organic. Soil inorganic carbon consists of mineral\nforms of C, either from weathering of parent material, or from reaction of soil\nminerals with atmospheric CO2. Carbonate minerals are the dominant form of soil\ncarbon in desert climates. Soil organic carbon is present as soil organic matter.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It includes relatively available C as fresh plant remains and relatively inert\nC in materials derived from plant remains: humus and charcoal.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil organic carbon is\ndivided between living soil biota and dead biotic material derived from\nbiomass.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Together these comprise the soil food web, with the living component\nsustained by the biotic material component. Soil biota includes earthworms,\nnematodes, protozoa, fungi, bacteria and different arthropods.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Detritus resulting from\nplant senescence is the major source of soil organic carbon. Plant materials,\nwith cell walls high in cellulose and lignin, are decomposed and the\nnot-respired carbon is retained as humus.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cellulose and starches are easily\ndegraded, resulting in relatively short residence time. More persistent forms\nof organic C include lignin, humus, organic matter encapsulated in soil\naggregates, and charcoal. These resist alteration and have long residence\ntimes.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil organic carbon\ntends to be concentrated in the topsoil. Topsoil ranges from 0.5% to 3.0%\norganic C for most upland soils. Soils with less than 0.5% organic C are mostly\nlimited to desert areas. Soils containing greater than 16 % organic C are\ngenerally classified as organic soils. High levels of organic C develop in\nsoils supporting wetland ecology, flood deposition, fire ecology, and human\nactivity.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fire derived forms of\ncarbon are present in most soils as unweathered charcoal and weathered black\ncarbon. &nbsp;Soil organic C is typically 5 -\n50% derived from char, with levels above 50% encountered in mollisol, chernozem,\nand terra preta soils.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Root exudates are\nanother source of soil carbon.&nbsp; &nbsp;12% of the total plant carbon fixed during\nphotosynthesis is supplied as root exudates in support of rhizospheric\nmutualistic biota.Microbial populations are typically higher in the rhizosphere\nthan in adjacent bulk soil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Organic carbon is vital\nto soil capacity to provide edaphic ecosystem services. The condition of this\ncapacity is termed soil health, a term that communicates the value of\nunderstanding soil as a living system as opposed to an abiotic component.\nSpecific carbon related benchmarks used to evaluate soil health include CO2\nrelease, humus levels, and microbial metabolic activity.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The exchange of carbon\nbetween soils and the atmosphere is a significant part of the world carbon\ncycle. Carbon, as it relates to the organic matter of soils, is a major\ncomponent of soil and catchment health. Several factors affect the variation\nthat exists in soil organic matter and soil carbon; the most significant has,\nin contemporary times, been the influence of humans and agricultural systems.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Although exact\nquantities are difficult to measure, human activities have caused massive losses\nof soil organic carbon. &nbsp;First was the\nuse of fire, which removes soil cover and leads to immediate and continuing\nlosses of soil organic carbon.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Increasing soil\ncarbon is not a straightforward matter; it is made complex by the relative\nactivity of soil biota, which can consume and release carbon .</span></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When we bypass nature\nand supply nitrogen in an inorganic form (synthetic fertilisers), there is no\nrequirement for the plant to supply exudates to the soil microbes that in turn\nsupply nitrogen to the plant.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is\nbecause the plant already has access to luxury levels of nitrogen.&nbsp; This means we have interrupted the process by\nwhich plants deliver stable carbon to the soil, and soils are subsequently\nbeing depleted of their carbon stores.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This becomes a vicious\ncycle, as the lower carbon stores mean the CEC of the soil is lowered and less\nnutrients (including nitrogen) are able to be stored in the soil.&nbsp; Even more nitrogen then needs to be added to\ncompensate for less being held in the soil \u2013 and so the cycle continues.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The ways that we can\nreinstate these things , these are:--<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ensure living ground\ncover all year round \u2013 with cover cropping or pasture cropping<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Reduce inputs of high\nanalysis fertilisers \u2013 as these interrupt the natural process of the plant\nsignalling soil microbiology that certain nutrients are required.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Maximise biodiversity \u2013\na variety of plants supports a great variety of microorganisms, which in turn\nsupply a greater variety of nutrients to the plants.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Add animals to the\nsystem \u2013 this adds another layer of biodiveristy and can help to maximise the\nliquid carbon pathway. In India our holy topsoil has been sustained by wood ash\nand humped cow dung .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Be aware however, that\nby practicing the above things, we are not going to achieve a completely\nhealthy, microbe rich functioning soil in just one crop season or year.&nbsp; So, we need to transition to it in a way that\nmaximises our crop yields and profitability.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The microbes in our\nsoils have a carbon to nitrogen ratio of around 8:1.&nbsp; In order to maintain this ratio in their\nbodies they must source both of these nutrients from their surrounding\nenvironment, which can come from organic matter in the soil.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Some of both the carbon and nitrogen is\nconsumed and remains in their bodies, while some carbon is also used as an\nenergy source after which it is released as carbon dioxide through the process\nof respiration.&nbsp; To maintain this ratio\nof 8:1 and also have enough extra carbon for energy consumption \u2013 the\nmicrobiology need to consume a diet with a C:N ratio of 24:1.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">At the consumption of food stuffs containing\nthis ratio, 16 of the 24 carbon are used for energy and 8 are for maintenance\n(the 8 of which ends up in their bodies).&nbsp;\nSo 24:1 is the perfect ratio on which the soil microbiology can feed.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Something like wheat\nstubble however, has a much higher C:N ratio, at 80:1.&nbsp; Given that the microbiology consume these two\nnutrients in the 24:1 ratio, it means that for every nitrogen consumed from the\nwheat stubble, there will be just 24 carbon consumed.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Leaving a spare 56 carbon.&nbsp; The microbiology will therefore need to seek\nnitrogen from elsewhere in the soil in order to be able to feed on this\nremaining carbon.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In being consumed,\nthis nitrogen then becomes contained in the bodies of these microbes and is\nimmobilised or unavailable to growing plants.&nbsp;\nIf enough of the nitrogen is immobilised, it can create a deficiency for\nthe plants that are growing in that soil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The nitrogen in the\nmicrobiology will eventually become available again as it is released through\nthe natural death and decomposition of the microbes via mineralisation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Conversely, if we were\nto supply an organic matter to the soil that had a low C:N ratio, like a &nbsp;crop which has a C:N ratio of 11:1 (much less\nthan the ideal 24:1), then the carbon will be consumed by the microbes, leaving\nexcess nitrogen available in the soil and for subsequent crops.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This excess nitrogen can have the same effect\nas applying high level inorganic fertilisers, in that it can result in the\ndecline of soil carbon &nbsp;Excess nitrogen\nmay actually stimulate soil microbes that then consume 24 carbon for every\nexcess nitrogen \u2013 thus depleting soil carbon.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A low C:N ratio cover\ncrop containing legumes (pea, lentil, cowpea, soybean etc )&nbsp; and/or brassicas (turnip, radish etc) can\nfollow a high C:N ratio crop such as corn or wheat, to help those residues\ndecompose, allowing nutrients to become available to the next crop.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Similarly,\na high C:N ratio cover crop that might include corn, sorghum, sunflower, or\nmillet can provide soil cover after a low residue, low C:N ratio crop such as\npea or soybean, yet decompose during the next growing season to make nutrients\navailable to the following crop.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As organic matter\nbreaks down, nitrogen is released. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">With every 10\u00b0C\nincrease in temperature the rate of organic matter mineralisation doubles. At\ntemperatures of 30-40\u00b0C, nitrogen can be mineralised at a rate of 10-15kg N/ha\nper day in moist soils.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Microbial activity is\ntypically limited in summer but is very responsive to summer rainfall and\nmeasureable activity is underway in only 15 minutes after a rainfall event.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The impact of\nmineralisation on a N budget and fertiliser decisions depends on a range of\nfactors such as the timing of mineralisation, the quality and quantity of the\nstubble load, the soil type, rainfall, crop choice and existing levels of soil\nN. What does C:N mean and why does it matter?<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Low quality stubbles\nsuch as wheat stubble have a wide C:N ratio (for example, 120:1) whereas\nmicrobes have a C:N ratio of approximately 12:1. The C:N ratio of residues\ndetermines whether soil nitrogen is immobilised (not plant available) or\nmineralised (supplied) during organic matter breakdown.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The general rule of\nthumb is that below a C:N ratio of 22, nitrogen can be released from organic\nmatter and made plant available.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Micro-organisms that\nlive within the plant root (for example, endophytes, rhizobium) are far more\nlikely to survive than those added to the bulk soil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil moisture\nconditions and availability of labile carbon (food for the microbes) will\nimpact greatly on their survival.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are six billion\nmicro-organisms in just a handful of soil, so you need to consider whether the\nproduct is providing a function that is not already supported by those that are\nalready present in your soil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Micro-organisms that are\ncapable of entering and residing in plant roots (for example, endophytes) are\nmore likely to survive after introduction to the soil/plant whwereas\nmicroorganisms introduced into the bulk soil have to compete for food and avoid\npredation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The activity and\nbiomass of microbes is supported by increasing amounts of plant production\nwhere organic matter inputs are retained. Increasing amounts of biological\nactivity can then be associated with a healthier soil, greater resilience to\npathogens and more nutrient supply. The relationship between microbes and plant\nproduction is very cyclical.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is evidence of a\nlink between microbial biomass, biological soil N supply and yield, though it\nis not the primary driver.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Alkaline soils are more\nprone to N losses through volatilisation. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil organic matter is\nprimarily plant residues, in different stages of decomposition. The\naccumulation of SOM within soil is a balance between the return or addition of\nplant residues and their subsequent loss due to the decay of these residues by\nmicro-organisms. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">SOM is important\nbecause it improves both the physical and chemical properties of soil and has\nseveral beneficial effects on agricultural soil quality. SOM helps stabilize\nsoil particles, thus decreasing erosion.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It also improves soil structure and\nworkability, enhances aeration and water penetration, increases water-holding\ncapacity, and stores and supplies nutrients for growth of both plants and soil\nmicro-organisms.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Climatic conditions,\nsuch as temperature and rainfall, exert a major influence on the amount of\norganic matter found in soil. Typically, accumulation of organic matter in soil\nis greater where there is more precipitation and cooler temperatures.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Decomposition of organic matter is greater in warmer, drier climates. Other\nfactors that affect the rate of organic matter decomposition include soil\naeration, pH level, and the microbial population of the soil.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Organic carbon (OC) is\nan essential part of all organic compounds. Soil organic matter generally\ncontains approximately 56% OC. The following equation is used to estimate the\ntotal organic matter content of soil from OC measurements: % Organic Matter = %\nOrganic Carbon x 1.78</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrogen (N) is\nabsorbed from soil and used by plants in its inorganic form, as either nitrate\n(NO 3- ) or ammonium (NH4 + ). Both forms occur naturally in soils and are\ncommon components of inorganic fertilizers.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrate is the principal form in\nwhich nitrogen is taken up by plants, due to its mobile nature and greater abundance\nthan ammonium. However, inorganic N represents only 4 % of the total nitrogen\nin the soil. Most soil N is bound to organic matter and not readily available\nto plants.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Total nitrogen (TN) is a measure of both inorganic and organic forms\nof nitrogen and is expressed as a percentage. Levels of N vary with temperature\nand moisture in the same way as levels of SOM, that is, N increases with cooler\ntemperatures and more moisture.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil C:N ratios tend to\nbe lower in arid regions than in humid regions, when annual temperatures are\nabout the same. Soil C:N ratios are also lower in warmer regions than in cooler\nones, if rainfall is equal. The C:N ratio is generally lower in subsoil than in\ntopsoil.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mineralisation\ndescribes the process whereby organic forms of nitrogen (N) in the soil are\nconverted to available forms of N. This process is driven by microorganisms\npresent in the soil decomposing organic matter for their energy supply. These\nmicro-organisms require N to build protein for their body tissues.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As the\norganic matter is decomposed the micro-organisms use some of the energy\nreleased from the organic matter whilst the rest is returned to the soil. The\namount of N available to plants depends on the carbon N ratio of the organic\nmatter (C:N ratio).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Organic matter with a high C:N ratio eg. 30:1 will\nmineralise slower than organic matter with a lower C:N ratio eg .14. If the\norganic matter has a higher C:N ratio then some of the mineral N that may\nalready be present in the soil will be utilised by the micro-organisms leading\nto N immobilisation. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The surplus N that is\nreleased by the microbial activity and not utilised by the micro-organisms is\npresent in the soil as nitrate or ammonium N and can be utilised by a crop. Any\nN that is immobilised by the micro-organisms will be slowly released back into\nthe mineral N pool as the micro-organisms die and their bodies decompose. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Once the organic matter\nbreakdown has commenced the first product produced is ammonium N via the\nbreakdown of proteins, amino acids and other compounds. This process is known\nas ammonification.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the presence of oxygen (aerobic conditions), moisture and\nthe correct temperature range the ammonium N is quickly converted to nitrate N\nby specialist nitrifying bacteria. Most nitrogen is taken up in the nitrate\nform.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mineralisation relies\nupon adequate moisture and oxygen and will be greatest when conditions in the\nsoil are favourable for plant growth. Significant mineralisation occurs\nfollowing summer rainfall especially where there are significant organic carbon\n(OC) levels in the soil.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mineralisation in the\nsummer months is generally considered to be significant following more than\n15mm of rain in one event. Rainfall events in excess of 15mm onto soil warmed\nby the summer heat provide the perfect conditions for increased soil microbial\nactivity.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/QCCQzHbxzJ0/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/QCCQzHbxzJ0?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: left;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: left;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">One gram of soil can\ncontain more than 10 million organisms. Without them, nothing would grow. The\nmicroorganisms are after carbon. And the plant roots will leak out carbon\ncompounds that attract the microorganisms. In exchange, the microbes break down\norganic matter in the soil, which delivers nitrogen and phosphate in a form\nthat the plant can use.&nbsp; So there is this\nbeautiful nutrient cycle around the plant root.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A nutrient cycle (or\necological recycling) is the movement and exchange of organic and inorganic\nmatter back into the production of living matter. The process is regulated by\nfood web pathways that decompose matter into mineral nutrients. Nutrient cycles\noccur within ecosystems. Ecosystems are interconnected systems where matter and\nenergy flows and is exchanged as organisms feed, digest, and migrate about.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Minerals and nutrients accumulate in varied densities and uneven configurations\nacross the planet. Ecosystems recycle locally, converting mineral nutrients\ninto the production of biomass, and on a larger scale they participate in a\nglobal system of inputs and outputs where matter is exchanged and transported\nthrough a larger system of biogeochemical cycles.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The nutrient cycle is\nnature's recycling system. All forms of recycling have feedback loops that uses\nenergy in the process of putting material resources back into use. Recycling in\necology is regulated to a large extent during the process of decomposition.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ecosystems employ biodiversity in the food webs that recycle natural materials,\nsuch as mineral nutrients, which includes water. Recycling in natural systems\nis one of the many ecosystem services that sustain and contribute to the\nwell-being of human societies.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ecosystems are capable\nof complete recycling. Complete recycling means that 100% of the waste material\ncan be reconstituted indefinitely. Grazing activity is accompanied by excretion\nof substances which are in turn used by the bacteria, so that the system more\nor less operates in a closed circuit.&nbsp; We\nin India knew this several thousands of years ago and this is recorded in our\nancient texts..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Earthworms, passively\nand mechanically alter the nature of soil environments. Bodies of dead worms\npassively contribute mineral nutrients to the soil. The worms also mechanically\nmodify the physical structure of the soil as they crawl about (bioturbation),\ndigest on the moulds of organic matter they pull from the soil litter.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These\nactivities transport nutrients into the mineral layers of soil. Worms discard\nwastes that create worm castings containing undigested materials where bacteria\nand other decomposers gain access to the nutrients. The earthworm is employed\nin this process and the production of the ecosystem depends on their capability\nto create feedback loops in the recycling process<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-u8keQvI1lOo/WRmMeedTi4I/AAAAAAABTXk/-Jffh6R3i2gIdSl23xTy9F9ZDOXIkeCQACLcB/s1600/imahbges.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"299\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-u8keQvI1lOo/WRmMeedTi4I/AAAAAAABTXk/-Jffh6R3i2gIdSl23xTy9F9ZDOXIkeCQACLcB/s400/imahbges.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both;\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fungi contribute to\nnutrient cycling and nutritionally rearrange patches of ecosystem creating\nniches for other organisms.. In that way fungi ingrowing dead wood allow\nxylophages to grow and develop and xylophages in turn affect dead wood,\ncontributing to wood decomposition and nutrient cycling in the forest floor.\nOur snake grove humus soil in which ayurvedic herbs grew in abundance was essentially\na fungi bank<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/L2yb1ERU9p4/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/L2yb1ERU9p4?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 250%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-size: large;\"><b>Organic\nfarming has sustained India for millennia. &nbsp;Industrial KOSHER farming, on the other hand,\nhas managed to create a series of unsustainable situations in less than 60\nyears, and evidence suggests we will not make it for another 20 years if we\ncontinue along the path of degenerative food and farming. &nbsp;&nbsp;</b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: large;\"><b>Our Rothschild\u2019s APCO branded PM Modi wanted to interlink all Indian rivers with the help of his white Jewish masters\nin Israel -- see he loves kosher VIKAAASSSSS ...&nbsp;</b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: large;\"><b>Gujju no 2 &nbsp;even wrote a book on GLOBAL WARMING \u2013 probably by divine spontaneous\nknowledge .</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/ZgWLAkBvOG8/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/ZgWLAkBvOG8?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b>I WILL EXPLAIN AGAIN IN\nLAYMANs LANGUAGE FOR THE LOWEST COMMON DENOMINATOR , SINCE PADMA VIBHUSHAN&nbsp; RECEIPIENTS TRIPLE <span style=\"color: red;\">ENZYME </span>SRI AND SADGURU\n<span style=\"color: red;\">GREENHANDS</span> VASUDEV WILL NO LONGER PRETEND TO BE TECHNICAL EXPERTS IN CHEMISTRY\n---<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b>ON MY SHIPS IS I SEE AN\nIDIOT PRETENDING TO BE AN EXPERT\u2014 I CALL HIM INTO MY CABIN AND BLEED HIM.<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b>IF YOU DON\u2019T KNOW \u2013JUST\nSHUT THE FUCK UP \u2014OR WE LOSE LIVES ON CHEMICAL TANKERS <o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Carbon to Nitrogen\nratio (C:N) is a ratio of the mass of carbon to the mass of nitrogen in a\nsubstance. For example, a C:N of 10:1 means there is ten units of carbon for\neach unit of nitrogen in the substance. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soil microorganisms\nhave a C:N ratio near 8:1. They must acquire enough carbon and nitrogen from\nthe environment in which they live to maintain that ratio of carbon and\nnitrogen in their bodies.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Because soil microorganisms burn carbon as a source\nof energy, not all of the carbon a soil microorganism eats remains in its body;\na certain amount is lost as carbon dioxide during respiration.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">To acquire the\ncarbon and nitrogen a soil microorganism needs to stay alive (body maintenance\n+ energy) it needs a diet with a C:N ratio near 24:1, with 16 parts of carbon\nused for energy and eight parts for maintenance. It is this C:N ratio (24:1)\nthat rules the soil!<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If foodstuff such as\nmature alfalfa hay (C:N ratio of 25:1) is added to the soil , the soil\nmicroorganisms will consume it relatively quickly with essentially no excess\ncarbon or nitrogen left over. The hay has an almost perfect balance of carbon\nto nitrogen that soil microorganisms (24:1) need.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">What would happen if we\nadded a foodstuff with a higher C:N ratio to the soil&nbsp; such as wheat straw with a C:N of 80:1?&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Since\nwheat straw contains a greater proportion of carbon to nitrogen than the 24:1\nperfectly balanced diet soil microorganisms require, the microbes will have to\nfind additional nitrogen to go with the excess carbon to consume the wheat\nstraw. This additional nitrogen will have to come from any excess nitrogen\navailable in the soil.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As soil microorganisms tie up excess nitrogen\n(immobilization), this situation could create a deficit of nitrogen in the soil\nuntil some of them die, decompose, and release nitrogen (mineralization)\ncontained in their bodies, or some other source of nitrogen becomes available\nin the soil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Conversely, what would\nhappen if we added a foodstuff with a lower C:N ratio, such as a hairy vetch\ncover crop with a C:N of 11:1? Since the vetch contains a lesser proportion of\ncarbon to nitrogen than the 24:1 perfectly balanced diet soil microorganisms\nneed, the microbes will consume the vetch and leave the excess nitrogen in the\nsoil.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This surplus nitrogen in the soil will be available for growing plants,\nor for soil microorganisms to use to decompose other residues that might have a\nC:N ratio greater than 24:1.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Everything else being\nequal, materials added to the soil with a C:N ratio greater than 24:1 will\nresult in a temporary nitrogen deficit (immobilization), and those with a C:N\nratio less than 24:1 will result in a temporary nitrogen surplus\n(mineralization).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is why composting operations strive to achieve a blend\nof materials with a C:N ratio of about 30:1\u2026 so the resident microbes can\nreadily decompose the compost pile leaving a little food and structure left\nover to feed and shelter the microbes after the compost is applied to the soil.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">By adding a relatively\nlow C:N ratio crop such as hairy vetch (11:1) to the rotation, nitrogen will be\navailable to the soil microorganisms, thus allowing them to break down the\nwheat straw more quickly.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Likewise, a cropping system of continuous no-till\npeas would result in very little soil cover as soil microbes would consume the\npea residue (C:N of 29:1) relatively quickly, as not much additional nitrogen\nwould be necessary for decomposition of the residue to take place.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It should now be\napparent from the discussion of C:N ratios and soil cover that management\nchoices must strike a balance between crop residues covering the soil and\nnutrient cycling. An awareness of crop C:N ratios is necessary to select crop\ntypes and keep a cropping sequence on the right path toward sustainability,\nthat of the ultimate C:N ratio of 24:1 that supports soil microorganisms.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If crops with high C:N\nratios are grown too frequently in the rotation, residues will accumulate on\nthe soil surface, and nitrogen for crop growth may be scarce unless\nsupplemented with other sources of nitrogen. This may result in poor crop\nperformance during times when soil microorganisms tie up nitrogen while working\nto decompose high C:N ratio crop residues.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cover crops added to a\ncash crop rotation can help manage nitrogen and crop residue cover in a\ncropping sequence.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A low C:N ratio cover\ncrop containing legumes (pea, lentil, cowpea, soybean, sunn hemp, or clovers)\nand/or brassicas (turnip, radish, canola, rape, or mustard) can follow a high\nC:N ratio crop such as corn or wheat, to help those residues decompose,\nallowing nutrients to become available to the next crop.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Similarly, a high C:N\nratio cover crop that might include corn, sorghum, sunflower, or millet can\nprovide soil cover after a low residue, low C:N ratio crop such as pea or\nsoybean, yet decompose during the next growing season to make nutrients\navailable to the following crop.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-size: large;\">Some&nbsp; C:N Ratio:--</span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">rye straw 82:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">wheat straw 80:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">oat straw 70:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">corn stover 57:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">rye cover crop\n(anthesis) 37:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">pea straw 29:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">rye cover crop\n(vegetative) 26:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">mature alfalfa hay 25:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">rotted barnyard manure\n20:1</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">legume hay 17:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">beef manure 17:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">young alfalfa hay 13:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">hairy vetch cover crop\n11:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">soil microbes (average)\n8:1<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If the C:N ratio is too\nhigh (excess carbon), decomposition slows down. If the C:N ratio is too low\n(excess nitrogen) you will end up with a stinky pile.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">To grow, microbes need\ncarbon for energy and nitrogen to build proteins. For every twenty to thirty\ncarbon atoms they consume, they use about one nitrogen atom. If that nitrogen\nis not available from the newly-added organic material, microbes will take it\nfrom the soil, and deprive growing plants of nitrogen.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The nitrogen is not lost\nfrom the soil - it is still present in the cells of microbes - but plants\ncannot use it. During this initial decay process, microbes are giving off large\namounts of CO2 to the atmosphere and the carbon-to-nitrogen ratio of the remaining\norganic material declines.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Microbial activity slows because the remaining\ncompounds are more recalcitrant (difficult to decompose). At this point,\nnitrogen from the dying microbes becomes available to plants. Organic matter is\nthe vast array of carbon compounds in soil.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Originally created by plants,\nmicrobes, and other organisms, these compounds play a variety of roles in\nnutrient, water, and biological cycles.
