Levels of nitrates in groundwater in some instances are above the\nsafe levels proposed by the EPA and thus pose a threat to human health. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrate is a problem as\na contaminant in drinking water (primarily from groundwater and wells) due to\nits harmful biological effects. High concentrations can cause\nmethemoglobinemia, and have been cited as a risk factor in developing gastric\nan intestinal cancer. reducing the amount of fertilizers used in agriculture\nwill help alleviate the problem, a reducing the amount of fertilizer used, the\nconcentration of nitrate in the groundwater can be reduced over time.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Treatment processes,\nsuch as ion exchange can have an immediate effect on reducing levels in\ndrinking water. These processes do not remove all the nitrate, but can help to\nbring the concentration down to the suggested level of 10mg/L.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Shallow aquifers\nunderlying sandy soils&nbsp; are highly\nsusceptible to nitrate contamination. These aquifers are vulnerable to impacts\nfrom land use activities such as septic systems, lawns, and agricultural\ninputs. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Once contamination\noccurs, responding to nitrate problems can be complicated and expensive. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Typically, reverse\nosmosis can reduce nitrates by 85 to 95% but actual removal rates vary\ndepending on the initial water quality, system pressure, and water temperature.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">An ion exchange system\nworks by passing contaminated water through a resin bead filled tank. The resin\nis saturated with chloride which chemically trades places with the similarly\ncharged nitrate ion. Eventually the resin needs to be recharged by backwashing\nwith a sodium chloride solution. The presence of sulfates can reduce the\nefficiency of the nitrate removal.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrates in\nconcentrations above 10 parts per million (ppm) expressed as N (this can be\nexpressed as 35.7 ppm as calcium carbonate or 44.3 ppm as nitrate) are\nconsidered unsafe in drinking water. Nitrates have no detectable taste or smell\ncompared with ordinary substances in water, so nitrate removal processes must\neither be foolproof or include extensive monitoring of the treated water.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">High nitrate levels\ninterfere with the ability of the infant\u2019s blood to carry oxygen.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ion exchange resins\nhave long been used for nitrate removal. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The ion exchange\nprocess for the removal of nitrates is both simple and effective. It operates\nin the same manner as a common water softener and can easily remove well over\n90 percent of the nitrates. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The process uses a\nstrong-base anion exchange resin, which is regenerated with common salt (NaCl)\nor potassium chloride (KCl) (use 1.27 pounds of KCl to replace each pound of\nNaCl regenerant with virtually identical results). The chloride ion of the salt\nis utilized by the resin. The sodium ion passes right through the resin bed and\ndoes not affect the process.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrate get into water\ndirectly as the result of runoff of artificial fertilizers containing nitrate.&nbsp; Nitrate can also be formed in water bodies\nthrough the oxidation of other, more reduced forms of nitrogen, including\nnitrite, ammonia, and organic nitrogen compounds such as amino acids. Ammonia\nand organic nitrogen can enter water through sewage effluent and runoff from\nland where manure has been applied or stored.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrate standards take\ntwo forms: drinking-water standards, designed to prevent adverse human-health\neffects, and ambient-water standards, designed to prevent excessive\neutrophication in lakes and streams. EPA standard in USA is 10 milligrams per\nliter (measured as nitrogen). <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This means managing\nagricultural operations to minimize application of fertilizer and to minimize\nrunoff of fertilizer that is applied example Switzerland, drinking-water\nproviders enter into contracts with farmers in their source areas in which\nfarmers receive subsidies to eliminate fertilizers and use organic farming\nmethods. Prevention also means proper handling of manure and animal waste\nlagoons, to minimize the discharge of animal waste or waste runoff to streams. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Western nations who use\nartificial fertilisers use advanced ion-exchange technology to remove excess\nnitrate and remain below the 10 mg/L standard. In a typical year, this is\nneeded mostly during the spring, following spring runoff after the application\nof fertilizer.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Phosphates exist in\nthree forms: orthophosphate, metaphosphate (or polyphosphate) and organically\nbound phosphate each compound contains phosphorous in a different chemical\narrangement.&nbsp; These forms of phosphate\noccur in living and decaying plant and animal remains, as free ions or weakly\nchemically bounded in aqueous systems, chemically bonded to sediments and\nsoils, or as mineralized compounds in soil, rocks, and sediments.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Orthophosphate forms\nare produced by natural processes, but major man-influenced sources include:\npartially treated and untreated sewage, runoff from agricultural sites, and\napplication of some lawn fertilizers. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Orthophosphate is a\nreadily available to the biological community and typically found in very low\nconcentrations in unpolluted waters..&nbsp;&nbsp;\nThe organic phosphate is the phosphate that is bound or tied up in plant\ntissue, waste solids, or other organic material.&nbsp; After decomposition, this phosphate can be converted\nto orthophosphate.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Unlike nitrogen,\nphosphate is retained in the soil by a complex system of biological uptake,\nabsorption, and mineralization.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;\nPhosphates are not toxic to people or animals unless they are present in\nvery high levels. Digestive problems could occur from extremely high levels of\nphosphate<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">In situations where\neutrophication occurs, the natural cycles become overwhelmed by an excess of\none or more of the following: nutrients such as nitrate, phosphate, or organic\nwaste.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">The excessive inputs, usually a\nresult of human activity and development, appear to cause an imbalance in the\n\"production versus consumption\" of living material (biomass) in an\necosystem.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The system then reacts by producing more phytoplankton/vegetation\nthan can be consumed by the ecosystem. This overproduction can lead to a variety\nof problems ranging from anoxic waters (through decomposition) to toxic algal\nblooms and decrease in diversity,&nbsp; food\nsupply, and habitat destruction.&nbsp;&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Under aerobic\nconditions (presence of oxygen), the natural cycles may be more or less in\nbalance until an excess of nitrate (nitrogen) and/or phosphate enters the\nsystem. At this time, the water plants and algae begin to grow more rapidly\nthan normal. As this happens there is also an excess die off of the plants and\nalgae as sunlight is blocked at lower levels.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bacteria try to decompose the\norganic waste, consuming the oxygen, and releasing more phosphate which is\nknown as \"recycling or internal cycling\". Some of the phosphate may\nbe precipitated as iron phosphate and stored in the sediment where it can then\nbe released if anoxic conditions develop.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In&nbsp; anaerobic conditions (absence of oxygen), as\nconditions worsen as more phosphates and nitrates may be added to the water,\nall of the oxygen may be used up by bacteria in trying to decompose all of the\nwaste.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Different bacteria continue to carry on decomposition reactions,\nhowever, the products are drastically different. The carbon is converted to\nmethane gas instead of carbon dioxide, sulfur is converted to hydrogen sulfide\ngas.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Some of the sulfide may be precipitated as iron sulfide. Under anaerobic\nconditions, the iron phosphate precipitates in the sediments may be released\nfrom the sediments making the phosphate bioavailable.&nbsp; This is a key component of the growth and\ndecay cycle.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The pond, stream, or lake\nmay gradually fill with decaying and partially decomposed plant materials to\nmake a swamp, which is the natural aging process.&nbsp; The problem is that this process has been\nsignificantly accelerated.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">ARTIFICIAL FERTILISERS\nCAUSES NITRATE OVERLOADING IN LAKES\u2014READ THIS TWICE.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">WHEN INDIA USED ORGANIC FERTILISERS WE NEVER\nHAD THIS PROBLEM..&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; color: red; font-size: x-large;\"><b>ARTIFICIAL FERTLISERS HAS KILLED 95% OF INDIAs LAKES</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Excess levels of\nnitrates in water create conditions that make it difficult for aquatic insects\nor fish to survive.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Algae and other plants\nuse nitrates as a source of food. If algae have an unlimited source of\nnitrates, their growth is unchecked.&nbsp; Large\namounts of algae can cause extreme fluctuations in dissolved oxygen.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/M3VDmhYQRrU/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/M3VDmhYQRrU?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Photosynthesis by algae and other plants can\ngenerate oxygen during the day. However, at night, dissolved oxygen may\ndecrease to very low levels as a result of large numbers of oxygen consuming\nbacteria feeding on dead or decaying algae and other plants.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Eutrophication&nbsp; is the process by which a body of water\nacquires a high concentration of nutrients, especially phosphates and nitrates.\nThese typically promote excessive growth of algae. As the algae die and\ndecompose, high levels of organic matter and the decomposing organisms deplete\nthe water of available oxygen, causing the death of other organisms, such as\nfish.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is this algae and\nwater hyacinths which convert a lake to a meadow<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-mTdIFWYOAcI/WRZyMS3BU4I/AAAAAAABTQM/yOcYqZwg820P5NzCRj1yIHrifvLzJuL-wCLcB/s1600/332935-d009fe22sssef0ecdf1ba0481ccbf1ca4aa.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"442\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-mTdIFWYOAcI/WRZyMS3BU4I/AAAAAAABTQM/yOcYqZwg820P5NzCRj1yIHrifvLzJuL-wCLcB/s640/332935-d009fe22sssef0ecdf1ba0481ccbf1ca4aa.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Anoxia is a lack of\noxygen caused by excessive nutrients in waterways which triggers algae growth.\nWhen the plants die and decay, oxygen is stripped from the water, which then\nturns green or milky white and gives off a strong rotten egg odour.&nbsp; The lack of oxygen is often deadly for\ninvertebrates, fish and shellfish.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrates and nitrites\nare families of chemical compounds containing atoms of nitrogen and oxygen.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrates&nbsp; may be a friend of agriculture... but it is a\ngreat enemy to lakes <o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/46oIaB4Niuo/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/46oIaB4Niuo?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Critical levels of\nphosphorus in water, above which eutrophication is likely to be triggered, are\napproximately 0.03 mg/l of dissolved phosphorus and 0.1 mg/l of total\nphosphorus.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The discharge of raw or treated wastewater, agricultural drainage, washing\nmachine phosphate infused detergent discharges , or certain industrial wastes\nthat contain phosphates to a surface water body may result in a highly\neutrophic state, in which the growth of photosynthetic aquatic micro- and macro\norganisms are stimulated to nuisance levels.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-tvKZnU6M_3I/WRZy9Uy7AmI/AAAAAAABTQU/o7jvNmO081AxrqMp-AL-HOWQJvlXi8egQCLcB/s1600/eutrophicfation.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"506\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-tvKZnU6M_3I/WRZy9Uy7AmI/AAAAAAABTQU/o7jvNmO081AxrqMp-AL-HOWQJvlXi8egQCLcB/s640/eutrophicfation.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;As algal mats and aquatic plants die, they\nsink to the bottom, where their decomposition by microorganisms uses most of\nthe oxygen dissolved in the water. The decrease in oxygen severely inhibits the\ngrowth of many aquatic organisms, especially more desirable fish (e.g.,\nrecreational catch fish such as trout) and in extreme cases may lead to massive\nfish kills.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Excessive input of phosphorus can change clear, oxygen-rich,\ngood-tasting water into cloudy, oxygen-poor, foul smelling, and possibly toxic\nwater. Therefore, control of the amount of phosphates entering surface waters\nfrom domestic and industrial waste discharges, natural runoff, and erosion may\nbe required to prevent eutrophication. <o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/tyzcR_0NLLs/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/tyzcR_0NLLs?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Phosphates, are used in\nartificial fertilizers,. Phosphates are classified as orthophosphates (PO -3 4\n, HPO -2, H 4 2PO4 , and H3PO4); condensed phosphates, or polyphosphates, which\nare molecules with two or more phosphorus atoms, oxygen atoms and in some\ncases, hydrogen atoms, combined in a complex molecule; and organically-bound\nphosphates.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Orthophosphates in an aqueous solution can be used for biological\nmetabolism without further breakdown. Orthophosphates applied to agricultural\nor residential cultivated land as fertilizers may be carried into surface\nwaters with storm runoff.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Polyphosphates may also be added to water supplies\nduring culinary water treatment . Polyphosphates slowly undergo hydrolysis in\naqueous solutions and are converted to the orthophosphate forms.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Organic\nphosphates are formed primarily by biological processes. They enter sewage water\nthrough body wastes and food residues. They may also be formed from\northophosphates in biological treatment processes and by receiving water\norganisms.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Like polyphosphates, they are biologically transformed back to\northophosphates. One means of surface water protection from phosphorus addition\nin both domestic and industrial wastewaters is the use of phosphorus removal\nprocesses in wastewater treatment.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrites occur in water\nas an intermediate product in the biological breakdown of organic nitrogen, being\nproduced either through the oxidation of ammonia or the reduction of nitrate.\nThe presence of large quantities of nitrites is indicative of waste water\npollution. The level considered ideal for marine fish is between 0.01 and 0.04\nppm.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/BosHU4ARR9w/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/BosHU4ARR9w?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Carbon dioxide (CO2) is\npresent in water supplies in the form of a dissolved gas. Typically, surface\nwaters contain less than 10 ppm free carbon dioxide while ground waters may\nhave much higher concentrations. Dissolved in water, CO2 forms carbonic acid\nwhich lowers pH.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Aquatic plant life,\nfrom phytoplankton to large rooted plants, depends upon carbon dioxide and\nbicarbonates in water for growth. Of significance for fish is the fact that\nwhen the oxygen concentration falls (e.g. through the degradation of organic\nwastes), the carbon dioxide concentration rises.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This increase in carbon\ndioxide makes it more difficult for fish to use the limited amount of oxygen\npresent. To take in fresh oxygen, fish must first discharge the CO2 in their\nblood stream, a process which is slowed down considerably when there are high\nconcentrations of CO2 in the water itself. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Most test kits do not measure below 10 mg/L,\nso if you get a reading on this test, you know your water body is in trouble.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ammonia nitrogen (N) is\npresent in variable concentrations in many surface and ground water supplies. A\nproduct of microbiological activity, ammonia when found in natural water is\nregarded as indicative of sanitary pollution.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ammonia is rapidly\noxidized by certain bacteria, in natural water systems, to nitrite and\nnitrate--a process that requires the presence of dissolved oxygen. Ammonia,\nbeing a source of nitrogen is also a nutrient for algae and other forms of\nplant life and thus contribute to overloading of natural systems and cause\npollution.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In fish, ammonia\nrepresents the end-product of protein metabolism and what is important is\nwhether it is present in the un-ionized form as free ammonia, NH3, which is\ntoxic to fish (both freshwater and marine) at &gt;0.03 mg/L (ppm), or in the\nionized form, NH4+, in which it is innocuous. The relative concentration of\neach is pH and temperature dependent.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The higher the pH, the more of the NH3\nwill be present. Ammonia can block oxygen transfer in the gills of fish,\nthereby causing immediate and long term gill damage. Fish suffering from\nammonia poisoning will appear sluggish and come to the surface, as if gasping\nfor air. In marine environments, the safe level of NH4+ is between 0.02 and\n0.4.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The USEPA recommends a\nlimit of 0.02 ppm as NH3 in freshwater or marine environments. Total ammonia\nlevels, at this limit, can range from 160 ppm at pH 6 and temperature of 5\ndegrees C to 0.06 ppm at pH 9 and temperature of 25 degrees C.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Nitrates occur in water\nas the end product in the biological breakdown of organic nitrogen, being\nproduced through the oxidation of ammonia . Although not particularly toxic to\nfish, excess nitrates in the water is used as an indicator of poor water\nquality.&nbsp;</span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/LwVpdvTxMQg/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/LwVpdvTxMQg?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Under anaerobic conditions, such as in the sludge or soil at the\nbotton of a pond, lake or aquarium, denitrification can be used to convert\nnitrate back to nitrite and from there to nitrogen gas, removing total nitrogen\nfrom the aquatic system. In marine environments, levels of 0.1 to 0.2 are\nconsidered ideal.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Levels exceeding 50\nmg/L (ppm) nitrate-nitrogen are&nbsp; unhealthy\nfor lakes.&nbsp; Levels from 10 mg/l to 40\nmg/l indicate poor water in aquariums, depending on the species being raised.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-HXLLPo9evO4/WRZ6e1vkeDI/AAAAAAABTQk/8ifSQLNJLzUpXTY6U1qWsYF-7FDE2l3EACLcB/s1600/Luthy_Pwwwage_20.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"480\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-HXLLPo9evO4/WRZ6e1vkeDI/AAAAAAABTQk/8ifSQLNJLzUpXTY6U1qWsYF-7FDE2l3EACLcB/s640/Luthy_Pwwwage_20.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><i>KRUPAYA\nDHYAAN DEEJEYE, PSSSSSSTTT &nbsp;-- The\nphosphorus and nitrogen cycles in lakes are linked. Although phosphorus content\nlimits algae growth, the organisms consume at least 40 times more nitrogen. The\nalgae convert reactive nitrogen (in the form of nitrates, or NO3) into inert\nnitrogen gas (N2), which can be released into the atmosphere or deposited in lake\nsediments. In this way, algal blooms function as nitrogen sinks removing\nnitrate pollution from the water. So as phosphorus levels in a lake increase,\nalgae remove nitrogen more quickly. And if phosphorus supply declines, the\nalgae population declines, and there is no mechanism to remove excess nitrates\nfrom the water. A lake with a high phosphorus content removed a larger\npercentage of nitrate inputs than one with a low phosphorus content.&nbsp; Lakes with higher phosphorus levels not only\nremoved nitrogen faster, but did so more efficiently. While phosphorus\npollution is controlled to limit algal blooms, nitrate pollution has proliferated,\ncreating these unforeseen challenges.&nbsp;</i></span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-mMZkNw6yft8/WRZ6v8VvXPI/AAAAAAABTQo/BDLHFTb8kesz9qJyz3hXyctWiCnKj0lVACLcB/s1600/Beeeioreactors-Take-on-The-Dead-Zone--1.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"316\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-mMZkNw6yft8/WRZ6v8VvXPI/AAAAAAABTQo/BDLHFTb8kesz9qJyz3hXyctWiCnKj0lVACLcB/s640/Beeeioreactors-Take-on-The-Dead-Zone--1.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Phosphates are the\nleading cause for algae growth in natural water bodies. Because dissolved <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">phosphorous is readily\navailable, algae can use it easily. In addition to consuming oxygen, some algae\nspecies release toxic substances into the water..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b>Iron oxide on carbon\nsteel surfaces is highly reactive with phosphates.&nbsp;&nbsp;</b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b>You can optimize the procedure by\npumping simulated drainage water first through a column filled with wood chips\nand then one filled with steel byproduct in an upflow reactor. &nbsp; &nbsp;</b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b>A 24-hour flow time through the wood chips\nand eight hours through the steel byproduct. &nbsp;</b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b>After three &nbsp;months of continuous\noperation, the column reactors can &nbsp;COMPLETELY&nbsp; remove nitrates and phosphates.&nbsp;</b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrates\nare not utilized by aquatic organisms such as fish and aquatic insects, but\nnitrates are used by aquatic plants.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/BosHU4ARR9w/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/BosHU4ARR9w?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">All aquatic organisms\nexcrete wastes and aquatic plants and organisms eventually die.&nbsp; These activities create ammonia.&nbsp; Some bacteria in the water change this ammonia\nto produce nitrite which is then converted by other bacteria to nitrate.\nNitrates (NO3-) are an oxidized form of nitrogen and are formed by combining\noxygen and nitrogen.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrates also come from\nthe earth.&nbsp; Soil contains organic matter,\nwhich contains nitrogen compounds.&nbsp; Just\nlike the ammonia in water, these nitrogen compounds in the soil are converted\nby bacteria into nitrates.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Although nitrates occur\nnaturally in soil and water, an excess levels of nitrates can be considered to\nbe a contaminant of ground and surface waters.&nbsp;\nMost sources of excess nitrates come from human activity.&nbsp; The source of excess nitrates can usually be\ntraced to MODERN agricultural activities, human wastes, or industrial\npollution.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple; font-size: large;\"><b>BAN NITRATE FERTIISERS\nIN CITY LAWNS AND GOLF COURSES.&nbsp; ..&nbsp;</b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple; font-size: large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple; font-size: large;\"><b style=\"background-color: white;\">GOVT\nMUST GIVE AN ORDER TO USE ONLY ORGANIC FERTILISERS ..</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Organic fertilizers\nsuch as manures, compost or bone meal are derived directly from plant or animal\nsources. Inorganic are often called commercial or synthetic fertilizers,\nbecause they go through some manufacturing process..&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Inorganic fertilizers\nusually contain only a few nutrients \u2013 generally nitrogen, phosphorus,\npotassium and some sulfur, either singly or in combination These nutrients are\nin a concentrated form readily available to plants. However, since they are\nlost from the soil quickly, you may have to apply it several times during the\ngrowing season unless you use a specially formulated, slow-release type.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Some\nnutrients, such as nitrate, are quickly available for uptake by plant\nroots.&nbsp; When you need only a certain\nelement such as nitrogen and want it to be quickly available to your plants, an\ninorganic fertilizer such as ammonium nitrate is OVER USED..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Organic fertilizers\nusually contain many plant nutrients in low concentrations. Many of these\nnutrients have to be converted into inorganic forms by soil bacteria and fungi\nbefore plants can use them, so they typically are more slowly released, over\ntime.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\">With organic fertilizers soil crusting and hardening ( cutting off oxygen\n)&nbsp; is reduced and water retention is increased.</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Organics improve water\nmovement into the soil and, in time, add structure to the soil. Organics feed\nbeneficial microbes, thereby making the soil easier to work.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple; font-size: large;\">Synthetic\nfertilizers can seriously deplete the nutritional content of foods.This is why\nEVIL PHARMA is thriving in India-thanks to the GREEN REVOLUTION of desh drohis .&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\">Direct contact or exposure to synthetic\nchemical fertilizers can kill babies..&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the U.S., generally there are three hyphenated numbers (for example:\n15-5-10) on the front label of fertilizer bags representing the percentage of\neach element by weight in the bag. The elements represented are N, P, and K.\nNitrogen, Phosphorus, and Potassium.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For example, the expression\n\"15-5-10\" means: 15% of the bags weight contains Nitrogen, 5% of the\nbags weight contains phosphorous, and 10% of the bags weight contains\nPotassium. You will notice in the above example that 15-5-10 add up to a total\nof 30% of the weight of the bag.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">What is in the other 70% of the bag?&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is not\ndisclosed. It does not have to be revealed. It can be just about\nanything...including, and often, industrial waste.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Some things this mysterious\n70% could contain are clay, sand, sawdust, perlite, rice hulls, calcium\ncarbonate (to dampen the detonation properties of the Nitrogen's ammonium\nnitrate), corn cob grit, vermiculite, limestone, sludge, slag, industrial\nwaste.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Of the 29 major fertilizers tested at random some were major and popular brands. Lead, mercury, arsenic, cadmium, barium,\nchromium, nickel, beryllium, dioxin, etc.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The metals found in\nthese fertilizers are known or suspected carcinogens, reproductive and\ndevelopmental, liver, and blood toxicants\u2014 toxic fertilsers are meant for third\nworld nations to depopulate</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Organic farmers must\nwait 90-120 days between application of raw manure and the harvest of any\norganic crop which may be eaten raw, which allows the fresh manure time to\ncompost and thus, prevent the spread of any potentially dangerous bacteria.\nBack to N-P-K. Nitrogen, Phosphorus, Potassium.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are 72 naturally occurring\nmineral elements. These are just three of them. These are essential for plant\ncell growth Nitrogen (when forcibly fed to plants) is known for promoting rapid\nexcessive green growth (much like steroids in a human). Nitrogen is the big\nplayer in commercial fertilizers. The appearance is a rapid lush green growth\nwhen applied on the lawn.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Some chemicals listed on a bag of fertilizer could be\ncalcium nitrate, sodium nitrate, potassium nitrate, ammonium sulfate, urea,\nammoniated super-phosphate, triple super phosphate (probably one of the most\nharmful to soil quality), potassium chloride, potassium sulfate, potash.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There\nare about 50,000,000,000 (fifty billion) microbes in a tablespoon of healthy\norganic humus topsoil soil. Many more near the roots of plants. Their primary\njob is to breakdown organic matter and to also feed plants.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">You could have\nevery element in its proper proportion available in the soil, but without the\nmicrobial action plants would not be able to utilize them. Synthetic chemical\nfertilizers actually inhibit, kill and alter this natural microbial activity\nwhich is so very important to healthy plants. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: x-large;\"><b>ARTIFICIAL FERTILIZERS\nARE LIKE ANTIBIOTICS WHICH KILL OFF GOOD BACTERIA.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: x-large;\"><b><br /></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white; color: blue; font-size: x-large;\"><b>WHY DOES IT TAKE A\nBLOGGER TO TELL ALL THIS ?</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2017/04/small-intestinal-bacterial-overgrowth.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2017/04/small-intestinal-bacterial-overgrowth.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b>WHY DOES IT TAKE A\nBLOGGER TO TELL INDIA THAT INTER CONNECTING RIVERS WILL KILL THE WATAN ? <o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b>AND ACCORDING TO PM MODI\nONLY ISRAEL CAN DO THIS.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b>BECAUSE ISRAEL HAS\nTHOUSANDS OF MIGHTY RIVERS RIGHT, JEW DARLING APCO MODI ?<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b><br /></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b>MODI , DO YOU SEE LONG\nEARS ON INDIANS ?<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/05/interlinking-rivers-of-india-capt-ajit.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2014/05/interlinking-rivers-of-india-capt-ajit.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In healthy soil there\nare herds of microbes near the roots of plants which out-compete pathogenic\nspecies and form a protective layer on the surface of living plant roots.\nMicrobes are essential in making minerals available to plants and they also\nretain large quantities of nutrients (such as nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium,\nsulfur, etc.) in their bodies which helps to prevent these nutrients from being\nleached or washed away. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Some microbes eat the\ndead cells of other microbes thus retaining the nutrients within the soil. In\nthe natural process, predator organisms which eat other microbes get too much\nnitrogen in relation to the carbon that they require. It takes 30 parts of\ncarbon to assimilate one part of nitrogen in a normal soil. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When the predator\nmicrobe consumes excessive amounts of nitrogen, it is released into the soil as\nnitrate. Plants can only use nitrogen in the nitrate form. (For example,\nammonia nitrogen can not be accessed by plants until it is broken down into the\nnitrate form by microbial action.) <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrate is very water\nsoluble. A variety of consequences occur when plants are forcibly fed too much\nnitrogen, especially in the direct nitrate forms you have seen in synthetic\nfertilizers.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The plant can absorb\nonly so much nitrate. Nitrate dissolves VERY easily in water. But the real\nclincher is that it is EXTREMELY difficult to remove from water. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">So, the excess nitrate\ngets washed away. It does not filter out of water through the soil. Generally,\nthe farther water travels through soil, the safer it becomes as contaminants\nare diluted or filtered out. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nitrate is the\nexception. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It can ruin well water\nand one would have to dig a new well where no nitrate leaching has occurred.\nThis processing of organic matter, nutrients and minerals is immensely complex\nand delicate. It is almost laughable to think that one can throw three elements\nin the form of synthetic chemicals onto the soil and say: Now I have balanced\nthe mineral and biological and ion and ph and microbial content of the soil. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The exact OPPOSITE\noccurs. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">GM companies who market\ntheir fertilisers don\u2019t tell you all this.&nbsp;\nGM companies do not want to help third waorld nations. They just want\ncontrol by having food and water resources in kosher control\u2026<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">They give kickbacks to\nSLAVE POLITICIANS WHO WANT NOBEL PRIZE even if it kills their motherlands\n.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Microbes are destroyed\nor inhibited in their balance when synthetics arrive. Microbes help to provide\nproper ph. Organic material alive with microbes is electrically charged and so\nthere is ion action. The artificial force feeding of these three elements throw\nthe balance of other minerals and nutrients completely off within the plant. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This stresses the\nplant, making the plant deficient in nutrients. Stressed plants attract\ndiseases and pests. That is nature's way of handling the sick. Then, because\nthe plant has bugs or a fungus, someone comes along with a chemical pesticide\nor fungicide in order to try to remedy the situation. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In fact, many soil\nmicrobes directly attack and kill insect pests, and many also directly fight\noff plant diseases. An example is sulfur uptake into the plant can be inhibited\nby artificial fertilizers<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\"><b>INDIANS WERE THE FIRST\nON THE PLANET TO DO AGRICULTURE \u2013 WE TAUGHT THE REST OF THE PLANET.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\"><b>TODAY DUE TO SOME JEW\nLOVING AND BRANDED POLITICIANS , THE REVERSE IF HAPPENING . <o:p></o:p></b></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\"><b style=\"background-color: white;\">NOT ANY MORE !</b></span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b>WE DEMAND THAT GROUND WATER MANAGEMENT BE A\nPART OF EVERY SCHOOL NCERT TEXT BOOK IN EVERY CLASS STARTING FROM FIFTH\nSTANDARD. &nbsp;&nbsp;</b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b style=\"background-color: white;\">THIS IS WHY I AM PENNING THIS POST</b><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In addition to animal\nwaste, untreated human sewage can contribute to nitrate levels in surface and\nground water.&nbsp; Leaking or poorly\nfunctioning septic systems are a source of such nitrates. In India the govt has\nnot regulated septic tanks. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;
