, serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/e2Ffs5gMk4g/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/e2Ffs5gMk4g?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">NGT HAS LANDFILLS IN THEIR BLIND SECTOR.&nbsp; &nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/c2Tr-U0nALM/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/c2Tr-U0nALM?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">THE\nBUCK DOES NOT STOP AT THE NGT TABLE IN INDIA.&nbsp;\n<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/WHXKUekd2qU/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/WHXKUekd2qU?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\">IF AS A CAPTAIN I DO ONLY FINGER POINTING LIKE NGT &nbsp;,\nMY CREW WILL THROW ME OVERBOARD</span><o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/20Ihfe6X_UM/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/20Ihfe6X_UM?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: left;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Poor practices of waste\nmanagement carried out at landfill sites and the absence of leachate collection\nsystem has a enormous impact on the ground water quality of local aquifer.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In India &nbsp;( especially in Kerala) many burial and\ngraveyard sites are over vulnerable aquifers. Drinking such aquifer water\ncauses brain diseases<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Garbage landfills are\nsupposed to have a protective bottom layer to prevent contaminants from getting\ninto the water. However, if there is no layer or it is cracked, contaminants\nfrom the landfill (car battery acid, paint, household cleaners, etc.) can make\ntheir way down into the groundwater.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Again, it is the job of\nthe govt to ensure that a landfill should be sited over a low vulnerability\naquifer.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Although landfills are\nan indispensable part of everyday living, they present long-term threats to\ngroundwater and also surface waters that are hydrologically connected.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The precipitation that\nfalls into a landfill, coupled with any disposed liquid waste, results in the\nextraction of the water-soluble compounds and particulate matter of the waste,\nand the subsequent formation of leachate. The creation of leachate, sometimes\ndeemed \"garbage soup,\" presents a major threat to the current and\nfuture quality of groundwater.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Monitoring wells at\nlandfills allow scientists to determine whether contaminants in leachate are\nescaping into the local groundwater system. The wells are placed downgradient\nof the landfill at appropriate depths and at various intervals to intercept any\ncontaminants and monitor their movement.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Monitoring wells at\nlandfills allow scientists to determine whether contaminants in leachate are\nescaping into the local groundwater system. The wells are placed downgradient\nof the landfill at appropriate depths and at various intervals to intercept any\ncontaminants and monitor their movement.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A number of forces may\nact on or react with the migrating leachate, resulting in changes of chemistry\nand a general reduction of strength from the original release.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These forces are\nphysical (filtration, sorption, advection, and dispersion), chemical\n(oxidation-reduction, precipitation-dissolution, adsorption-desorption,\nhydrolysis, and ion exchange), and biological (microbial degradation). The\nextent of these reactions depends on the materials underlying the landfill, the\nhydraulics of the groundwater system, and the chemistry of the leachate.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Although many of these\nreactions have the capability to reduce the potential impact to groundwater,\nsome (such as microbial degradation) can actually increase the toxicity by\nproducing by-products that are more hazardous than the original contaminant. This\ncan be seen, for example, in the creation of vinyl chloride from the\ndegradation of trichloroethene.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Today's landfills are\nconstructed with liners that contain leachate, and leachate collection systems\nthat collect it. But historically, many landfills were constructed without\nliners or leachate collection systems.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Landfills must be as far\naway from surface water as possible.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">The landfill can\nallocate pollutants for tens and hundreds of years.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The longer a landfill\nremains full of waste, the more the toxins from that waste seep into the soil\nbelow and around the landfill. This leads to groundwater contamination almost\nimmediately. When landfills are very large, the amount of groundwater polluted\nby them is significant.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In industrial\ncountries, waste that is too hazardous to landfill is routinely buried in\nunderground tanks but as these caskets age, like gasoline tanks, they\neventually spring leaks. In California's Silicon Valley, where electronics\nindustries store assorted waste solvents in underground tanks, local\ngroundwater authorities found that 85% of the tanks they inspected had leaks.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Silicon Valley has more Superfund sites - most of them affecting groundwater -\nthan any other area its size in the country and 60% of the United States'\nliquid hazardous wastes - 34 billion litres of solvents, heavy metals, and\nradioactive materials - is directly injected into the ground.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Although the effluent\nare injected below the deepest source of drinking water, some of these wastes\nhave entered aquifers used for water supplies in parts of Florida, Texas, Ohio,\nand Oklahoma<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-p-t5ic7wFzM/WRckyyhTn9I/AAAAAAABTSg/Lhm0430MYwUidi0ItnYmBlc01Y_dwAdAwCLcB/s1600/1w_2.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"400\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-p-t5ic7wFzM/WRckyyhTn9I/AAAAAAABTSg/Lhm0430MYwUidi0ItnYmBlc01Y_dwAdAwCLcB/s640/1w_2.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is obvious that a landfill\nshould be sited over a low vulnerability aquifer. Between a highly vulnerable\nand a moderately vulnerable aquifer the same decision might not be so clear and\nthe resultant action may depend on other specific issues at hand.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The reason is\nthat the &nbsp;hydrogeological information defining\nan aquifer\u2019s vulnerability varies in quality and quantity between aquifers.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-wHJezT3PSgM/WRckQFkEgkI/AAAAAAABTSY/peO9KU3_w_k-dD0837H34a1yB71ryeTDwCLcB/s1600/10.59ss23.j.env.20140405.03_002.gif\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"258\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-wHJezT3PSgM/WRckQFkEgkI/AAAAAAABTSY/peO9KU3_w_k-dD0837H34a1yB71ryeTDwCLcB/s640/10.59ss23.j.env.20140405.03_002.gif\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In order to predict how\nlong landfill leachate will continue to contaminate groundwater after a landfill\nis closed, it is critical to understand how effective natural processes are in\nremoving those contaminants over time.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Leachate is most\ncommonly used in the context of land-filling of putrescible or industrial\nwaste.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Leachate from a\nlandfill varies widely in composition depending on the age of the landfill and\nthe type of waste that it contains. &nbsp;It\nusually contains both dissolved and suspended material. The generation of\nleachate is caused principally by precipitation percolating through waste\ndeposited in a landfill.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-AuI1wuNDvks/WRddvQJP9QI/AAAAAAABTSw/Ia7-tViexA89f67pes_DnmgIczCBxUCfQCLcB/s1600/z002-contaminatSion-groundwater-a-waters-seeping-water-dumping-site-ENGL.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"380\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-AuI1wuNDvks/WRddvQJP9QI/AAAAAAABTSw/Ia7-tViexA89f67pes_DnmgIczCBxUCfQCLcB/s640/z002-contaminatSion-groundwater-a-waters-seeping-water-dumping-site-ENGL.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Once in contact with decomposing solid waste, the\npercolating water becomes contaminated, and if it then flows out of the waste\nmaterial it is termed leachate.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Additional leachate volume is produced during\nthis decomposition of carbonaceous material producing a wide range of other\nmaterials including methane, carbon dioxide and a complex mixture of organic\nacids, aldehydes, alcohols and simple sugars.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/_ayDO64aBSg/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/_ayDO64aBSg?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The risks of leachate\ngeneration can be mitigated by properly designed and engineered landfill sites,\nsuch as those that are constructed on geologically impermeable materials or\nsites that use impermeable liners made of geomembranes or engineered clay.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;The\nuse of linings is now mandatory within the United States, Australia and the\nEuropean Union except where the waste is deemed inert. In addition, most toxic\nand difficult materials are now specifically excluded from landfilling.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">However, despite much stricter statutory controls, leachates from modern sites\nare often found to contain a range of contaminants stemming from illegal\nactivity or legally discarded household and domestic products.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/epLv2t9kmos/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/epLv2t9kmos?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When water percolates\nthrough waste, it promotes and assists the process of decomposition by bacteria\nand fungi. These processes in turn release by-products of decomposition and\nrapidly use up any available oxygen, creating an anoxic environment.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In actively\ndecomposing waste, the temperature rises and the pH falls rapidly with the\nresult that many metal ions that are relatively insoluble at neutral pH become\ndissolved in the developing leachate.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The decomposition processes themselves\nrelease more water, which adds to the volume of leachate. Leachate also reacts\nwith materials that are not prone to decomposition themselves, such as fire\nash, cement-based building materials and gypsum-based materials changing the\nchemical composition.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In sites with large volumes of building waste, especially\nthose containing gypsum plaster, the reaction of leachate with the gypsum can\ngenerate large volumes of hydrogen sulfide, which may be released in the\nleachate and may also form a large component of the landfill gas.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/34Ro-nrVusE/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/34Ro-nrVusE?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In a landfill that\nreceives a mixture of municipal, commercial, and mixed industrial waste but\nexcludes significant amounts of concentrated chemical waste, landfill leachate\nmay be characterized as a water-based solution of four groups of contaminants:\ndissolved organic matter (alcohols, acids, aldehydes, short chain sugars etc.),\ninorganic macro components (common cations and anions including sulfate,\nchloride, iron, aluminium, zinc and ammonia), heavy metals (Pb, Ni, Cu, Hg),\nand xenobiotic organic compounds such as halogenated organics, (PCBs, dioxins,\netc.).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The physical appearance\nof leachate when it emerges from a typical landfill site is a strongly odoured\nblack-, yellow- or orange-coloured cloudy liquid. The smell is acidic and\noffensive and may be very pervasive because of hydrogen-, nitrogen- and\nsulfur-rich organic species such as mercaptans.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/s-ps_0UFmfI/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/s-ps_0UFmfI?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In older landfills and\nthose with no membrane between the waste and the underlying geology, leachate\nis free to leave the waste and flow directly into the groundwater. In such\ncases, high concentrations of leachate are often found in nearby springs and\nflushes.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As leachate first emerges it can be black in colour, anoxic, and\npossibly effervescent, with dissolved and entrained gases. As it becomes\noxygenated it tends to turn brown or yellow because of the presence of iron\nsalts in solution and in suspension. It also quickly develops a bacterial flora\noften comprising substantial growths of Sphaerotilus natans.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The primary criterion\nfor design of the leachate system is that all leachate be collected and removed\nfrom the landfill at a rate sufficient to prevent an unacceptable hydraulic\nhead occurring at any point over the lining system.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are many\ncomponents to a collection system including pumps, manholes, discharge lines\nand liquid level monitors. However, there are four main components which govern\nthe overall efficiency of the system. These four elements are liners, filters,\npumps and sumps.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Natural and synthetic\nliners may be utilized as both a collection device and as a means for isolating\nleachate within the fill to protect the soil and groundwater below. The chief\nconcern is the ability of a liner to maintain integrity and impermeability over\nthe life of the landfill.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/AYb91H593k4/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/AYb91H593k4?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Subsurface water monitoring, leachate collection, and\nclay liners are commonly included in the design and construction of a waste\nlandfill. To effectively serve the purpose of containing leachate in a\nlandfill, a liner system must possess a number of physical properties.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nliner must have high tensile strength, flexibility, and elongation without\nfailure. It is also important that the liner resist abrasion, puncture, and\nchemical degradation by leachate. Lastly, the liner must withstand temperature\nvariation and be black (to resist UV light), easily installed, and economical.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are several types\nof liners used in leachate control and collection. These types include\ngeomembranes, geosynthetic clay liners, geotextiles, geogrids, geonets, and\ngeocomposites. Each style of liner has specific uses and abilities.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Geomembranes are used to provide a barrier between mobile polluting substances\nreleased from wastes and the groundwater. In the closing of landfills,\ngeomembranes are used to provide a low-permeability cover barrier to prevent\nthe intrusion of rain water.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Geosynthetic clay liners (GCLs) are fabricated by\ndistributing sodium bentonite in a uniform thickness between woven and non-woven\ngeotextiles. Sodium bentonite has a low permeability, which makes GCLs a\nsuitable alternative to clay liners in a composite liner system.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Geotextiles\nare used as separation between two different types of soils to prevent\ncontamination of the lower layer by the upper layer. Geotextiles also act as a\ncushion to protect synthetic layers against puncture from underlying and\noverlaying rocks. Geogrids are structural synthetic materials used in slope\nveneer stability to create stability for cover soils over synthetic liners or\nas soil reinforcement in steep slopes.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Geonets are synthetic drainage materials\nthat are often used in lieu of sand and gravel. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The leachate drainage\nsystem is responsible for the collection and transport of the leachate\ncollected inside the liner. The pipe dimensions, type, and layout must all be\nplanned with the weight and pressure of waste, and transport vehicles in mind.\nThe pipes are located on the floor of the cell. Above the network lies an\nenormous amount of weight and pressure.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">To support this, the pipes can either\nbe flexible or rigid, but the joints to connect the pipes yield better results\nif the connections are flexible. An alternative to placing the collection\nsystem underneath the waste is to position the conduits in trenches or above\ngrade.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The collection pipe\nnetwork of a leachate collection system drains, collects, and transports\nleachate through the drainage layer to a collection sump where it is removed\nfor treatment or disposal. The pipes also serve as drains within the drainage\nlayer to minimize the mounding of leachate in the layer. These pipes are\ndesigned with cuts that are inclined to 120 degrees, preventing entry of solid\nparticles.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The filter layer is\nused above the drainage layer in leachate collection. There are two types of\nfilters typically used in engineering practices: granular and geotextile.\nGranular filters consist of one or more soil layers or multiple layers having a\ncoarser gradation in the direction of the seepage than the soil to be\nprotected.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As liquid enters the\nlandfill cell, it moves down the filter, passes through the pipe network, and\nrests in the sump. As collection systems are planned, the number, location, and\nsize of the sumps are vital to an efficient operation. When designing sumps,\nthe amount of leachate and liquid expected is the foremost concern.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Areas in\nwhich rainfall is higher than average typically have larger sumps. A further\ncriterion for sump planning is accounting for the pump capacity. The\nrelationship of pump capacity and sump size is inverse. If the pump capacity is\nlow, the volume of the sump should be larger than average. It is critical for\nthe volume of the sump to be able to store the expected leachate between\npumping cycles.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This relationship helps maintain a healthy operation. Sump\npumps can function with preset phase times. If the flow is not predictable, a\npredetermined leachate height level can automatically switch the system on.\nOther conditions for sump planning are maintenance and pump drawdown.\nCollection pipes typically convey the leachate by gravity to one or more sumps,\ndepending upon the size of the area drained.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Leachate collected in the sump is\nremoved by pumping to a vehicle, to a holding facility for subsequent vehicle\npickup, or to an on-site treatment facility. Sump dimensions are governed by\nthe amount of leachate to be stored, pump capacity, and minimum pump drawdown.\nThe volume of the sump must be sufficient to hold the maximum amount of\nleachate anticipated between pump cycles, plus an additional volume equal to\nthe minimum pump drawdown volume.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sump size should also consider dimensional\nrequirements for conducting maintenance and inspection activities. Sump pumps\nmay operate with preset cycling times or, if leachate flow is less predictable,\nthe pump may be automatically switched on when the leachate reaches a\npredetermined level.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">More modern landfills\nin the developed world have some form of membrane separating the waste from the\nsurrounding ground, and in such sites there is often a leachate collection\nseries of pipes laid on the membrane to convey the leachate to a collection or\ntreatment location<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">All membranes are\nporous to a limited extent so that, over time, low volumes of leachate will\ncross the membrane. The design of landfill membranes is at such low volumes\nthat they should never have a measurable adverse impact on the quality of the\nreceiving groundwater.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A more significant risk may be the failure or\nabandonment of the leachate collection system. Such systems are prone to\ninternal failure as landfills suffer large internal movements as waste\ndecomposes unevenly and thus buckles and distorts pipes.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If a leachate\ncollection system fails, leachate levels will slowly build in a site and may\neven over-top the containing membrane and flow out into the environment. Rising\nleachate levels can also wet waste masses that have previously been dry,\ntriggering further active decomposition and leachate generation.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Thus, what\nappears to be a stabilised and inactive site can become re-activated and\nrestart significant gas production and exhibit significant changes in finished\nground levels.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">One method of leachate\nmanagement that was more common in uncontained sites was leachate\nre-circulation, in which leachate was collected and re-injected into the waste\nmass. This process greatly accelerated decomposition and therefore gas\nproduction and had the impact of converting some leachate volume into landfill\ngas and reducing the overall volume of leachate for disposal. However, it also\ntended to increase substantially the concentrations of contaminant materials,\nmaking it a more difficult waste to treat.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The most common method\nof handling collected leachate is on-site treatment. When treating leachate\non-site, the leachate is pumped from the sump into the treatment tanks. The\nleachate may then be mixed with chemical reagents to modify the pH and to\ncoagulate and settle solids and to reduce the concentration of hazardous\nmatter. Traditional treatment involved a modified form of activated sludge to\nsubstantially reduce the dissolved organic content.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/SMrZ3XOVO-c/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/SMrZ3XOVO-c?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Nutrient imbalance can\ncause difficulties in maintaining an effective biological treatment stage. The\ntreated liquor is rarely of sufficient quality to be released to the\nenvironment and may be tankered or piped to a local sewage treatment facility;\nthe decision depends on the age of the landfill and on the limit of water\nquality that must be achieved after treatment. With high conductivity, leachate\nis hard to treat with biological treatment or chemical treatment.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Treatment with reverse\nosmosis is also limited, resulting in low recoveries and fouling of the RO\nmembranes. Reverse osmosis applicability is limited by conductivity, organics,\nand scaling inorganic elements such as CaSO4, Si, and Ba.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The risks from waste\nleachate are due to its high organic contaminant concentrations and high\nconcentration of ammonia. <o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/w1RKMMpRRHY/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/w1RKMMpRRHY?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Landfills exist not\njust to store waste, but to contain it. This is much more complicated than it\nsounds, because waste is often not inert; it doesn\u2019t just sit there and slowly\ndecompose.&nbsp; Instead, waste has a tendency\ntoleak, combine, mesh together, and react, creating new chemical compounds that\nweren\u2019t originally present or leaching out chemicals that were once contained.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Moisture passing through the landfill can pick up these compounds, known as\nleachates, and carry them into the soil or the groundwater supply, potentially\ncontaminating both. In many ways, proper landfill management is the science of\ncontaining leachates. A leachate liner is the single most important tool for\naccomplishing that.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/MKikQcAddKk/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/MKikQcAddKk?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Leachate liners come in\nseveral different types, for specialized purposes:--<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Clay liners. Certain clays are an\nincredibly effective barrier for leachates, and occasionally a landfill is\nfortunate enough to be sited somewhere where the natural clay or bedrock can\nsupport leachate containment. More commonly however, a synthetic clay made from\nsodium bentonite, a nearly impermeable substance that can be pressed between\ntextile layers to simulate a clay barrier, is used to contain leachates.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Geomembranes. Membranes are\neffectively impermeable, watertight barriers that are used both on top of a\nlandfill, to minimize surface water entry, and beneath, to protect groundwater.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Geotextiles are versatile liner\nlayers used for several purposes, including as a backing for synthetic clay\nliners. On their own, they are used between layers of different soils and are\nalso effective cushioning to protect other layers from puncture.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Geonets are used for drainage.\nNormally, the bottom of a landfill would contain layers of sand and gravel to\nhelp filter any moisture that makes its way down, but this takes up a great\ndeal of landfill space. Geonets provide the same filtering capacity as a 12-inch\nthick layer of sand.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Geogrids. Grids are primarily\nstructural elements and help anchor other features. They can help prevent other\nliner layers from slipping on slopes, and can also help anchor soil and\nvegetation used to cover a landfill.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/CSRQ2ikd7q4/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/CSRQ2ikd7q4?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Since leachate liners\nact to contain the liquids in a landfill, there needs to be a drainage system\nin place or the entire site will become waterlogged and, eventually, pollutants\nwould leak out the top. Leachate drainage systems are carefully engineered pipe\nsystems beneath the landfill that include provisions for both testing water\nquality and pumping out leachate-laden water for proper treatment and disposal.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<a href=\"https://floatingcovers.wordpress.com/tag/landfill-liners/\" style=\"background-color: lime;\"><span style=\"font-size: large;\">https://floatingcovers.wordpress.com/tag/landfill-liners/</span></a><o:p></o:p></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/tq7LlMXrr8Q/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/tq7LlMXrr8Q?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c2474767554962423590\" style=\"font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_142MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2017/05/false-narrative-capt-ajit-vadakayil.html<br /><br />I HAVE TRIED HARD TO EDUCATE ROTHSCHILDs APCO BRANDED MODI ABOUT WORLD INTRIGUE..
